description:
Really good happy hour place especially when you want a restaurant that has just enough people to be lively but not so crowded that it's body and hard to have a conservation in. 

$1 oyster - do I even need to keep talking? 

So the oysters are pretty fresh and better than a few other dollar oysters that are available in the city. Lao beer goes really well with their deep fried chicken wings and their calamari. 

The service is quick and friendly but when the restaurant fills up for dinner service, they are more inclined to clear your table for dinner parties.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
Came here for dinner before hitting up Hawthorne. 

Didn't even realize this is just the old Osha aka where I had my first real adult date back in 2008. I preferred the Osha. The ambiance is beautiful and the food is the same as Osha. I had the pineapple millionaire drink which was pretty good. Portions are big but the price is absurdly expensive for what it is. 

The worst thing about this place is my charged my friend per soda at like $6/Coke and it was literally all ice.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
We came to Lao table for the happy hour oysters as advertised on the website. 

When we told our server we wanted oysters she pushed us to order more food. She was very clearly unhappy with us. They only let you order 6 at a time. 

We ended up ordering more food anyway but the service throughout the night was mediocre. I had to ask for water multiple times. We were rushed to leave at the end. I thought she had asked us if we wanted more water but instead she said "we need the table. But take your time" and never brought any water. I hate this server! She did not deserve any tip but of course we still tipped the full amount on an already overpriced meal. 

Food wise, it's very mediocre for high prices, presented very instagrammable but tastes average. I won't be back and won't recommend it to others. There are many great happy hour or asian food options in the area, this restaurant seems like a faux-asian restaurant for tourists. 

For a great happy hour with $1 oysters, try bar Agricole.
author: Annie Z.

description:
True rating: 4.5
Here's the breakdown:

1. This is a semi-fancy restaurant. The pictures on Yelp didn't make it seem like that but once you walk in and look at the prices, it's not your everyday restaurant.

2. It was very lively when I went for a late Friday dinner at 8:15pm. The place was basically packed. There were a few birthday dinners, a few rowdy people in dress shirts, a few family, but mostly young professionals. It's a fun environment if you don't mind the noise.

3. It's really loud in here. I wouldn't recommend it for a first date because you have to shout for the other person on the other side of the table to hear you. And they ring this loud bell when it's someone's birthday. It's probably not that bad but I was sitting right underneath it so I heard it loud and clear. 

4. The service is a little odd. It's mostly waitress with sleeve-less shirts and statement earrings. You kind of get a Las Vegas vibe from the waitresses. They were kind and smily but it didn't feel personal. They seemed to just want to get the job done. I asked for recommendation and they basically pointed at the most expensive dishes on the menu. I'm not sure if that's because those were their specialties or not, but it felt like it was a routine the waitresses did from the customer perspective.  

5. There is Yelp reservations! Use it because you probably need a reservation on a busy weekend.

6. The interior is nice. It has dim lights to match the dark colors. I personally was a fan of the decorations and environment. 

7. The prices are on the pricy side. I got the Ka-Pow Lamb that was recommend for $26, the 'fresh coconut' drink for $8 and the Mark Mango (mango sticky rice) for $13. Prices are around $18 - $25 per dish

8. The food is good. The fresh coconut drink was nice and would recommend it if you don't mind spending the money for it. It comes in the coconut with a flower. The lamb was a bit too salty for my taste but it comes with white rice with some toned rice on top which helped balance it out. I'm not sure if I would get that again though. The mango ice with sticky rice was meh. I love shaved ice and have tried many shaved ice desserts and this was below average. But my friend really enjoyed the sticky rice.

Overall, I would recommend this to a friend if they are looking for a nice Thai restaurant. It's fancier than a regular restaurant so maybe save it for a special occasion and not be like me who was feeling Thai food and went to the closest Thai place near my place in jeans and a t-shirt. The food is pretty good, service is alright, and the atmosphere is fun.
author: Shin L.

description:
I researched Lao Table for several months and basically drooled over their photos before I visit San Francisco in August. It was at the top of "Places to Go" list and it didn't disappoint!! The BF was hesitant to go, but I turned him into a believer. 

We ordered the fresh spring rolls, Kurobota Pork Belly, and Spicy Steak Lao. We also ordered 2 really great drinks. I think one was called the Pineapple Millionaire and it was served in a giant pineapple which was so CUTE. The other was served in a fresh coconut. Honestly, I didn't even take photos or make a huge effort to remember the food and drink names because everything looked SO good that we just wanted to eat. The taste matched the presentation. Loved it!
author: Jessica A.

description:
My friend and I came for dinner and got the Grilled Calamari and the Garden Fish. The Grilled Calamari was very good and I would recommend all to get it. 

The reason for my 3 stars is the Garden Fish. For a $70 plate, our fish was actually overcooked. Also, the meats were all just okay, nothing amazing. I did not like the beef jerky. What I liked about the plate was all the fresh garden veggies to eat with the fish. On the side note, all the food is on a big, tall platter. I was barely able to see my friends face! 

Service was mediocre. Thai tea was bomb. Would I come back? I don't crave anything from here, but if a friend suggested to come I would go.
author: Darlene T.

description:
First time and probably last time. 

Not your typical restaurant or every day take out place. Kinda pricey. Me and the bf went here last night bc we were so hungry and we love Thai food, this place... not so much. It was very spicy, the meat was cooked very rare. I had the pineapple millionaire drink which was amazing of course I substituted my vodka for grey goose and he had a Hennessy and coke. 

Definitely a place to go for drinks but not something I'll crave or will eat here again. Service was very slow, the waitress took about 20 mins to even come greet us and get us some drinks, not even water at this point.
author: Jess S.

description:
I have been here twice, so I will be reviewing both times I went. The first was with a couple of friends (Friday at 8:45pm) and the second was with my mom (Friday at 6pm). Both times, I had created reservations the day of. The restaurant is sleek and classy, but seating is definitely close together and the lighting is pretty dark inside. 

The first time with my friends, we started off ordering several drinks. I ordered the Lao Soda ($13)- with lime vodka and watermelon. This was super good, it wasn't too sweet and was balanced nicely with the lime flavor. My friend ordered the Lao beer ($7) and the other ordered a Mai-Thai ($13)- which was really good, sweeter than mine but still not overly sweet.

For food we split the Lamb Zeen Beef Lettuce Wrap ($17.95) -made not spicy with minced beef flank steak lettuce wrap, toasted rice powder, and basil/mint. It was good portion, but the flavors did not seem all there for me (maybe it's because we said no spice). 

We also got the Khaw Kai noodles ($16.95) which came with thick rice noodles (so soft and good), chicken, peanuts, and a soy sauce with lettuce. The noodles were very flavorful, but I did not think there was enough of them and I wish there was more veggies in this dish. It is a small portion for what the price was. 

Lastly, we got the Lao Fried Rice ($18.95) which came with a fried egg and chicken wings which was a pretty good sized portion. It was a bit spicy and kind of plain other than the toppings listed above. Not the most favorited dish. 



On my second occasion, the food we got the Wrapping Vegetable Crispy Rolls ($13.95) that came with lettuce, basil/mint, and glass noodles on the side along with spring rolls with shiitake mushroom. It also came with a sauce that was supposed to be sweet/sour but was spicy. These were really good and crispy. I liked how they gave big pieces of lettuce and noodles to eat them with. 

We also got the Fresh Spring Rolls in the vegetarian version- which is with tofu instead of pork sausage ($13.95). A waitress was coming around with a cart of dishes that were $6 each and were 1/2 the portion of the the normal size, so we actually had got the fresh spring rolls in the regular meat version as well. My mom and I preferred the tofu version.
We both really enjoyed the peanut sauce, but thought that the rice paper wrap was way too thick for the rolls.

We ordered the mini lao fried rice with a chicken wing from the waitress going around with the cart ($6), and it was nothing special and a bit spicy (though probably not spicy for people who like spicy food, I just can't handle it personally). 

We also got the calamari from the happy hour menu and it was perfectly crisp and tender on the inside. To drink we split a Thai iced tea ($7) that came in this really pretty large round cup- it was very refreshing, but maybe a bit too much ice.

For dessert we got the Cha Yen Thai Tea Jumbo Icy ($19), which reminded me of halo halo. There was jackfruit, blackberries, grass jelly, strawberries, and some other toppings over Thai ice tea that they pour on top of the ice in front of you. It was really good, my issue was that some of the ice was so frozen so you couldn't scoop it easily as you would with shaved ice. 

Overall, both experiences were good, but a bit overpriced for the portion sizes.
author: April L.

description:
Food = bright, beautiful, and quite good! Service = what service?

Our work group of 4 came here for lunch, with a reservations. I was really giddy looking over the menu, because everything sounded so fantastic. I tried to choose things that I thought would help me stay awake and alert (or at least appear to be functioning) for the rest of the workday, so I paired the grilled calamari appetizer with a side of papaya salad. The papaya salad was still a large serving for a side, enough to share with the table for sure. It was crisp and a little salty and sweet, but it could have used some more heat. The grilled calamari was stunning - the whole squid was beautifully presented on a board with live flowers. It could have been more tender but I really enjoyed it with the dipping sauce. 

But yeah, it took a while to order, and we sat around with empty water glasses for a while. One of our entrees never arrived, and our server never came back to check on us. When we finally flagged her down, she didn't really give a damn about the missing entree. We all finished our meals and it still hadn't arrived so we had to flag her down again and ask for it to just be prepped as takeout. I also wonder if the presentation of the dishes tries to overcompensate for the overall experience?
author: Kara D.

description:
My friends and I were craving Asian food somewhere in SoMa near a BART station for a quick dinner, so we decided to to give Lao Table a try. I ordered the pineapple fried rice (no raisins), and my friends ordered the basil chicken and the Lao fried rice. 

Pineapple fried rice was pretty good and tasted similar to the pineapple fried rice at most Thai places I've been to. I also appreciated that they accommodated my request for no raisins.The basil chicken was very flavorful and a little spicy. The Lao fried rice came with fried chicken wings, which were delicious! Each dish was around $20, which is pretty typical for SF prices. 

Service was great - they came by to refill our waters and ask us how we were doing frequently. Side note: for birthdays, they ring a giant bell and sing! I was seated right next to the bell, so I was a little caught off guard by the loud noise. 

Overall, solid Thai/Lao place in SoMa that's a little pricey but still tastes pretty authentic!
author: Claudia L.

description:
Good food, but like everyone said slowish service. We ordered a whole bunch of things for the table:

Chicken wings: An excellent start - crispy on the outside and moist on the inside, my one complaint is that it could have used som sort of sauce 

Crispy rolls: I mean if you've had spring rolls before then this is nothing new. A safe and solid choice if you're unsure about what to get

Papaya salad: spicy and refreshing, I enjoyed that it came with noodles and a whole bunch of other mix-ins like shrimp, herbs, some sausage thing, etc

Laotian sausage: good flavor, just the right amount of spice

Oysters: Who can resist the $1 oyster happy hour? Let me tell you, don't get enticed by this offer if you stop by; tbh it was probably our own fault for ordering oysters at a Laotian place

Spicy eggplant: hey we needed some veg, and eggplant is always a good way to go - home style flavor with a lil kick

Pork knuckle: a gigantic pork knuckle - meat was tender in some places and a little dry in others, although it did fall off the bone quite easily

Laotian fried rice: was actually anticipating this one quite a lot, but managed to let me down. It just didn't really deliver on the umami factor, and was a little too sweet for my liking

Coconut dessert: bang on yes! The coconut ice cream was delicious and creamy and the warm sticky rice went perfectly with it.

Generally a good experience, I would potentially return and try some of the other offering from their pretty expansive menu.
author: Linda M.

description:
Showed up early and had a few drinks from their happy hour specials : Jameson julep and red wine. The Jameson Julep was too sweet for my liking and the red wine was decent. 

Everyone at the table kept saying, "the food here is good!"  Enough said. The food here is delicious. We had the papaya salad (Lao style), lamb chops, fried egg rolls wrapped with lettuce, fried rice, fried noodle dish, and spicy eggplant. Everything was so flavorful and cooked to perfection. Even though I was full, I kept eating. I could not stop!
author: Simon S.

description:
Wait/Ambiance: 
They always have Yelp reservations available, even day of, so I would recommend making a reservation. You could also just walk in -- they usually have tables available (you may have to wait 15-20 minutes). Ambiance is really nice with lots of colorful lamps, flowers, and lights. The restaurant is also conveniently located next to Montgomery Bart on 2nd Street.

Food: 
- I've only tried the garlic pepper pork and the minced chicken basil bowls here, both of which are delicious. I love that the bowls are a decent portion with a fried egg on top. However, the dishes seem a little overpriced to me (~$23 per bowl after tip and tax), but the portions are slightly enough for 2 meals if you're not ravenous.

Overall:
- Service all 3 times I've been here has been slow, and food can take a while to come out
- Flavorful food, but a little pricey
author: Victoria L.

description: Service and environment are really good in here. It's my first time trying Lao food and they tasted fairly good! Highlights: Basil Chicken, Roasted duck rice bowl.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
Great food plus not so great service equals an average three stars. I was in charge of a lunch group and we were limited on time and also had some dietary restrictions. Lao is close to our office and also fit the bill for everything we needed. 

I had a reservation and our table was ready right away which was great. We placed our order with the server after she filled our water glasses. After that, we had to flag down servers with water pitchers anytime we needed a refill. 

Our shared app of the fried vegetable spring rolls arrived looking and tasting delicious. A short time later, our entrees arrived... most of them. One member of our group didn't receive her entree and our server didn't even acknowledge that until we flagged her down to ask where it was. It was clear the order had been forgotten and had to be quickly made by the kitchen. We got it to-go because we were short on time at that point. 

In better news, my chicken basil entree was really large and very good. The shrimp entree to my left looked fantastic as well. 

If I went back for lunch, I might try sitting at the bar for more attentive service, since they were very busy in the restaurant. I'd be open to takeout in the future, as well. Not sure I'd recommend it for a seated lunch option, however.
author: Michelle C.

description: I went here yesterday and the food was very good. The papaya salad is great but beware it is spicy! The pho was also excellent and very flavorful!y favorite was the beef fish with the sticky rice. My only complain is that the music at the restaurant was quite loud so it was hard to hear my dinner companions. Also the waiter we had was very attentive, very helpful with dietary restrictions.
author: Tara K.

description: Came here with a group of 18 at 8:30 PM on a Wednesday. We pre-ordered and ate family style. At my request the apps were out within two minutes of us arriving and the service was on point all night long despite the fact the restaurant was busy (with the Oracle OpenWorld crowd). Food is worth the price and the atmosphere is solid (especially the server uniforms :)
author: Reid T.

description:
Lao Table is gorgeous, from the high ceiling decor to the plating and presentation. Hence how I was able to take some gorgeous pictures - thank you thank you.

The food also did not disappoint. I would highly recommend the Kurobuta Pork Belly - it was tender and delicious. The Tum Marg Hoong Papaya Salad was the right amount of spicy and came with yummy sides! I may skip the Red Curry Chicken next time - only because there's so many other delicious looking plates and this was just okay.

The only thing that dragged down the rating (besides the chicken, which was a little salty and tough) was service, but I'd definitely highly recommend a visit!
author: Claire W.

description: This place was amazing!! Let's start with the soup Tom Zaab Loa Beef... hands down best soup I've had a restaurant, it was spicy, flavorful, and full of beef! Done to perfect! Anytime I'm in town I must have this soup. Hail the soup gods for this concoction! Then there was the Lamb chop, perfectly medium, lots of flavor. Even the rice was a nice simple flavor. Next drinks, this is highly relative but I wish they had more alcohol but the were nice compliments to the meal. Lastly, I loved the ambience of this place, good customer service, laidback but lively, the lightly is perfect for a date or groups of friends. I can get loud but I enjoyed every bit of it.
author: Mikki A.

description: I am coming back - tomorrow! Had the "Tum Marg Hoong" Papaya salad - one of the best salads I ever had. It's spicy though but the flavors are amazing. The chef that came up with this dish and the different ingredients in it is a genius, no other way to put it. If you don't like flavor, stay away from this salad. I could probably eat a whole bucket of this thing. Note that the salad comes "deconstructed" in a way and you can either wrap in lettuce or just mix everything together. Either way try to mix as much as you can to get the max flavor out of this and did I say that the pork cracklings there are just genius? The add the crunchiness, just what this salad needed. The place looks awesome, good for a romantic date but also for a casual night out with good selection of music and even a few TVs above the bar, actually WAY above the bar, I bet after a full football game you will need to see a chiropractor... Food has San Francisco price tags, this is not going to be your value night out for sure. But the food is worth the price. Service was ok nothing special but definitely not bad.
author: Gil S.

description: Papaya salad was meh. Kind of overpriced for what it was and way too salty. Probably best to stick to hot or grilled menu items.
author: Lyle Z.

description: Fun atmosphere, good service and delicious food.  The perfect trifecta for a restaurant.  Highly recommended!
author: Duncan D.

description:
Big fan of Laoation food and had this place bookmarked forever.

Pros-

Nice ambiance (nicest I've been to for Lao)
Great service

Cons-
Average food
Extra pricy items

Shared:

papaya salad, was just average.

Crispy rice salad, was just like a kim chi fried rice and was extra sour/salty.  Didn't stay crispy and was just mushy

Crispy German pork knuckle- description was not accurate.  It was soft and mushy and not crispy at all.

Total for lunch for 2 people was $80 without drinks.  Unfortunately food was just not great.
author: Vi Y.

description: Beautiful restaurant with great ambiance, great food and great service. Kitty, Restaurant Manager was so gracious, courteous and professional. She made sure our group was taken cared well. All the food we ordered from appetizers to the main dishes and the drinks were so good and impeccable presentation. The Banana Blossom Salad was super good! Actually, all the orders we made are so good. The service was very pleasant and attentive. I was so impressed that I will surely come back soon.
author: Art M.

description: I come here for some lunch meetings because it's so convenient to book and always a spot available.  Good selection from the menu and the food is pretty solid.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
First impression: really classy place 
Second impression: the cost is on the higher side
Third impression: the food has so much quantity, worth every penny + delicious
Fourth impression: really classy place, as first impression is the last impression :p

Nice place for group lunch/dinner as well as date ;)
author: Sharad B.

description:
Food was decent but not great. The quality definitely didn't warrant the price though though. We were hoping for more authenticity but definitely feel that they catered their menu towards the general population. Oh well.

One big no-no for us was their lack of highchairs. NOT BABY FRIENDLY. We brought our 1yo on a baby carrier and found out about their seating situation the hard way.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I'm torn..... 3.5 sounds a bit better but the beer prices swayed me to a 4. Happy Hour beers were very well priced for SF and our group took full advantage. We then followed it up with 6 different appetizers and meals. The Foie Gras presentation was unique - a nice smokey glass dome but that was better than the "meat." The crispy spring rolls were delicious. The vegetarian rolls were spot on. I'd never seen whole calamari presented like it was - and it was decent. The steak lao had a very nice, slightly spicy sauce with it and was worth the $32.

Worthy of a return visit!
author: Kevin K.

description:
I have come here twice. The first time I would give 3 stars the second time I came I would give 1 star.

First time I came with my company for lunch. The food was alright and the prices are pretty high but that's SF for you.

Second time I came for the happy hour oysters. I placed my order and waited for 15 minutes and it still hasn't come. People who came in after me got their orders already. No one checked up on me either. I left
author: Xiao W.

description:
Every single dish here is sooo good! Highly recommend!
Will take all my Thai and American friends here. Service is 10/10. Will defo be back!
author: Mint Atchima T.

description:
2nd time here and although this is 100% treat yo self type lunch (price wise) it's kind of turning into a guilty pleasure...

I'm less and less likely to actually go and sit at a restaurant for lunch, but I feel like I need to more! 

The entrance is a little unassuming but once you open the door the place is huge. Even though it's been busy both times I didn't feel crammed. 

My favorite dish so far is the Om Chicken. It's a clear broth curry! Super flavorful and like having a really hearty broth. Definitely ordering this again next time. The sausage app is good too. I'm wanting to try one of the fish dishes next time.

Delish.
author: Heather H.

description:
This place is fantastic. I love the food here so much I come as often as possible!

The ambiance is really modern, and while crowded it's pretty easy to get a table. Less well-known: they also have takeout, but it's so nice you'll still want to stay. 

The Crying Tiger Steak is the yummiest thing I've had there, and is one of the best steaks of my life. It is spiced to perfection and juicy. I love the Pineapple Fried Rice, as well. The Mok Seabass is tasty, and a definite must try, as it soft and well spiced.
author: Jenée S.

description:
Highlights: perfectly fried, crispy eggs on rice bowls, grilled squid and ingredients tasted noticeably fresh, chicken & ginger rice was really flavourful and well done (A+ cus this dish can get super bland if not well done)

Pros: 
-- easy to make last minute reservations
-- popping but not overly crowded
-- beautiful / grammable presentation
-- food is actually delicious / all the classics you'd expect (ginger chicken rice, minced pork, fried pork belly, etc.) 

Cons: 
-- a bit pricey for moderate portions (~$16 per entree)
-- as mentioned by others, service on the slower side, you have to werk to flag down servers
author: Anna H.

description:
The food at Lao Table is actually not bad but I would not come back because:
1) service is non-existent.
2) food takes forever to come... Are they growing vegetables back there, fresh?

My table ordered food that shouldn't be too complex to make - fried rice, pan-fried noodles, curry dishes, etc, but it still took over half an hour for the food to come. We then tried to get a dessert (the Mark Mango) which took another twenty minutes to bring out. I didn't anticipate having to spend two hours at a dinner where half of it was me waiting for food and wouldn't want to pay as much money as I did for such a subpar experience.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
I don't get to the west coast often but when I do, I want to try all the foods! On my second day in the city we had reservations at Lao Table for lunch and I heard such amazing things, I was pumped. There were four of us and it was a great opportunity to enjoy some new grub while getting to know new coworkers/friends. When we arrived we were seated right away and handed menus to look over. They must have thought their menu was a novel because it was a while before someone came and took our order. Knowing that they have a lunch rush throughout the week, I assumed they would be adequately staffed. Woof! 

Despite the wait, I was pleased that they had some vegetarian options and I ended up ordering the basil rice bowl, vegetarian version of course. This meant that it came with tofu instead of chicken. As everyone's food started to come out, my stomach started rumbling. My dish ended up being the missing one from the table so I must have pulled the short stick. We asked our server (and even other servers) where my food was at several times. I was pretty bummed that there was no sense of urgency or even an apology from the staff. It was obvious that I was forgotten about and a simple "I'm sorry" would have left me feeling better about the situation. After being there almost an hour, I requested my food to be made to go so I could enjoy it later in the office. It had already been paid for or else I would have said forget about it. 

Thank goodness I was able to munch on the crispy vegetable rolls that we shared at the table. These were really tasty and everyone at the table enjoyed them. Later on when I was able to eat my lunch, I was happy with the amount of flavor in the basil rice. I bet if I had been able to eat it while I was there it would have been even better!

Overall, things happen and I totally get it. I'd like to think that my experience was an outlier and that this doesn't happen too often. Pro Tip - Make reservations for lunch outside of the 12-1PM time slot so they aren't as swamped. Otherwise, food was good and I really liked the aesthetic of the place. I would definitely give it another try... maybe for dinner next time.
author: Jayme H.

description:
My husband and I went here for date night last week. 
I was able to make last minute reservations through Yelp and when we checked in the place was really crowded.  It was a Friday night, after all. 
Our table wasn't ready when checked in, so we grabbed a couple of drinks at the bar.  My husband had bourbon and I tried the Millionaire's Pineapple drink.  Both drinks were good and before we knew it, our table was ready. 

We ordered the tuna tartare, crab curry and basil chicken.  The tuna tartare had a spicy kick to it and it was perfect!  I usually get basil chicken if I see it on the menu and their basil chicken is comparable to Osha Thai's.  For dessert, we had the shaved ice with fruit.  The food was good and the presentation was beautiful.  Pricing was a bit steep so that's the only thing that's stopping me from returning.  Service was also a bit slow but they were incredibly friendly.   Good to try with a big group.  It's a fun place and the food is good.
author: Christine P.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here in a weeknight and surprisingly it wasn't too busy and we got seated immediately.

What we got:

1) Crispy sticky rice salad: lots of herbs and a ton of flavor--we got exactly what we expected and I'd totally get this again. Those of you who are willing to try something new--get this! (fermented pork sausage can sound scary to some!)
2) Khaw Kai Noodles: we liked this dish as well, but didn't feel like it was anything special (it tasted similar to pad kee mao)

Overall, we'd definitely come here again! Loved the flavors--a lot of herbs were familiar to us (commonly used in SE Asian food) and made it that much more enoyable for us.

Service was attentive and friendly--we'll be back!
author: Shannon N.

description:
Thai restaurant in the heart of the financial district SF. I wouldn't eat here until you were working or just in the area because parking is extremely hard where the restaurant is located. On top of that, there was some major construction going on right outside blocking a few lanes of traffic. 

Food quality is good and on par with other Thai places in the city. They have a pretty extensive menu. The presentation of the food here is definitely a plus here and what probably makes them stand out. Some of our dishes, including my friend's Duck Pho, came out on its own presentation tray and was very "instagram worthy". I would definitely come back to eat here but a few stars knocked off due to the price in ratio to quantity (although it IS downtown and SF) and the customer service. My girlfriends and I had late lunch (2 pm-ish) and we were the only ones eating at the time but it still took a long time for our food to come out or for us to get more water.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Beautiful spot, cute, and romantic, attentive service, beautiful servers and bartenders work here.

Lao & Thai food, beautiful plating, fresh veggies and herbs, generous portion and fair priced.

Chicken Soup was delicious. 

Fried Pork Belly was so good. 

Veggies Egg Roll was OK.

Papaya Salad comes with egg,  pork skin, rice noodle and herb. Beautiful but lacks of flavor! 

We would love to come back to try other dishes and see what else is good there!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
This is a more upscale Osha Thai, which is owned by Osha Thai!  The decor got a little spruced up, the food remains delicious, and the service is still really good.  What is different is... the price, the portions, the flavors (but still yummy) and less crowded during lunch hour.  

We came and ordered:
:) Pork belly - this was very tender and soft.  I could had eaten more of this!
:) Basil chicken - basil shined through the minced chicken and is topped with a crunchy over easy egg.
:) Mok seabass - it was sooo small.  It came in a nice neat banana leaf and was packed with spicy flavors.  Wish it wasn't so dry, it could had been a bit more flakey and fluffy.

Overall, we had a good experience.  But the portions were too small and we ended up munching on snacks in the office afterwards.

To Lao Table:  Larger portions please!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Food here was epic.  The flavors and presentation were outstanding.  We tried so many things and all were perfect.  The drinks are totally done up with all the fringe extras.  It is very cramped in seating but we were louder than the table next to us so it worked out.

The spread:

*  wrapping crispy roll - super flavor.  There was a fight over not enough wrappers.
*  Moo Nam Pla - ordered two as the first one was gone before it made it around the table.
*  Chicken Satay - the most standard dish of all.  Worked but the most basic.
*  Lao Sausage - got mowed.
*  Calamari - not deep fried but grilled.  Healthy and tasty.
*  The duck over rice - took down two orders.
*  Intermittent Mai-Tai's during the app session.
*  Eggplant with meat - superior flavor.
*  Tomahawk - cut for the table to share.  What is not to like?
*  Red Curry - got wolfed quickly.  
*  Khao Poon - two of them were destroyed.  Flavor was off the chart.
*  Kha Moo German - basically a huge short rib, meat fell off the bone.

DO IT.
author: Greg S.

description:
Come to Lao and you'll definitely be treated to an experience with beautiful presentation.  Yes, you'll be charged a ton (like holy moly $7 for a thai iced tea), but when you see the way it is served to you on the fancy platters, you'll kind of understand why.  

For appetizers, I liked the chicken satay with peanut sauce.  The spring rolls were alright.  For lunch, I had the Khaw Khai noodles, which was tasty.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but I wish there were more noodles and less chicken though.  Also shared the Khao Nar Ped (duck rice), which I would recommend as well.  Thai iced tea was presented in such an elaborate and memorable way that it made me almost forgive the $7 charge.  From a taste perspective, it was a bit too sweet for my liking.

Service wasn't horrible, but it definitely could be improved upon.  Also highly suggest getting a reservation.  We were a big group (about 15) with a reservation and even then we had to wait a little for our table.  Also, it looked like more than half the restaurant had a reservation sign on the tables anyway.  I guess another room for improvement is that they really should've kept track of who ordered what rather than bringing the food and forcing everyone to sort out who has what.  I think it's fair to have that expectation when the food is this expensive.  

Overall, I wouldn't have an issue with coming back here if it was for a special occasion.  It's a nice switch up from the usual American or Italian food restaurants.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I have visited Lao Table a couple of times, mostly for team lunches (as they allow reservations for big groups). I've had a good experience overall.

The food is yummy and beautifully presented. That said, I've had some team mates who were slightly disappointed with their dish as well. I've eaten the Basil Chicken and the Red Curry with Chicken and was a happy customer.

Their service is hit or miss. One time we had to wait 45 minutes to get any food, and on another occasion our food arrived after 15 minutes. Staff is friendly and hard working.

The interior of the restaurant is classy. Dishes are quite expensive but not uncommonly so for this area. 

It's not a restaurant I would visit all the time but it's worth checking out. Would be good for a date night as well.
author: Ellen H.

description: This place has good food and a nice ambience. Their Thai Iced Coffee is really great, you should definitely try it out. There is a smaller selection of dishes compared to other Thai restaurants, but they are all great!
author: Wyatt S.

description:
Been here multiple times for lunch and it has not disappointed. I love how everything is beautifully presented in a deconstructed way. 

They use a lot of fresh vegetables in their dishes that bring the flavors alive. If you've never had Lao food, it's very similar to Thai food but different. I really like this place because they care about not only the flavor of the food but presentation! They make each dish look so beautiful with flowers and banana leaves. 

It's not the cheapest place to go for lunch but the flavors do not disappoint. 

In addition to their regular menu, they have happy hour! Make sure you come here for their $1 oysters and discounted drinks!
author: Mai W.

description:
I went here several times. I like their pad see you with their spicy sauce on the side. Forgot what it's actually called there. We got the $1 oysters, it was good. We wished it shucked, but I guess that's what we get for wanting cheap oysters.

My friend got the mango sweet rice and it was a massive tower. I couldn't help her. It was already too much food for me.

Came here several times, the presentation is awesome, but the food is okay. 

The first time I went here, I got the duck pho and it was very sweet.

Gave it 4 stars because it's close by and good happy hour options. The food here is kind of expensive though.
author: Kimberly D.

description: Loved this place!!!!!! It has a gorgeous interior and fun atmosphere. We started with the veggie spring rolls, so delicious and fresh. I had a noodle dish and my friend had the pho. The servings were huge, definitely more than we could eat in one sitting. The service was great, everyone was so attentive and friendly. I felt the amount of food and ambiance was well worth the price. They had a great cocktail list with a lot of fun and unique spirits. Next time we come back I can't wait to give the drinks a try! Definitely check this place out next time you're in soma!
author: Amanda J.

description: Trying something new...again. Food was wonderful. Presentation and taste were great. The atmosphere was trendy and upbeat. Definitely a chic place to hang out. Horrible service!! The waitress at the bar even noticed I wasn't getting help, so she walked AROUND the bar to help me. Pretty sad.
author: Olive R.

description: Hello friends this place is a solid for stars and very convenient for you folks that work in the financial district Soma or Embarcadero. Situated close to the new Salesforce Tower and transit station you will enjoy the authentic Laotian and Thai Dishes at the spot. My business partner and I ended up ordering the crispy pork, panang lamb Curry, and basil chicken. All the dishes had wonderful flavors and to top it off great ambiance and great service.
author: Ben C.

description:
My bf took me here for dinner and I didn't know what to expect but it was so good!!! When I first walked in, it was pretty busy and the decor is modern. We were seated right away since we had a reservation. They had an extensive menu with so many great options. So many things I wanted to try so I will definitely be back. However, it is on the pricey side. 

We went with the grilled squid, steak, fried pork belly, and finished off with dessert. I probably could've done without the fried pork belly, it was just alright for me. We ordered dessert thinking it was just the mango sticky rice but it also came with mango shaved ice! The mango flavor was fresh and not too sweet, which I prefer. Unfortunately we didn't finish it. But overall, a must try place if you like Lao/Thai food.
author: Kim N.

description: Wow. Amazing. Authentic food in a great atmosphere with awesome service. Can't get any better than this.
author: Danish M.

description:
Come for the fantastic Laotian and Thai food. But don't expect any fucks. They ran out of those a long time ago.

I came here with a group of colleagues with a 90 minute timeframe. Since we had a reservation and were able to walk right in and get a table, we assumed it'd be a smooth process. Nope. These servers are terrible. Like so terrible it has to be on purpose. Like aggressively terrible. They took forever to take our order. They didn't seem to understand that the glasses on the table were meant to contain water. They decided that one person in our group simply didn't need to eat for at least 15 minutes after the rest of us. They completely ignored our requests to pay. They sucked. I definitely won't be coming back.

But hey! The food was so good, and the presentation is gorgeous! We split the Wrapping Vegetable Crispy Rolls (otherwise known as egg rolls?) and they were a perfect start to the meal. For an entree I had the Totally Prawns curry. OMG delicious, a red coconut curry with pineapple and lychee to add some sweet. Just a hint of spice. I loved it! My dining partner got the calamari, which was prepared an presented in a way I'd never before seen! A whole squid split and chargrilled, it was something I'd definitely want to order again. If I were to ever come back. Which I won't.

PS - their pride campaign is really disappointing. Simply a photo of one of their servers shirtless, with "$1 oysters" typed over it. Lazy and transparently just an attempt to get in on the gay dollar. Plus, you should probably wear a shirt when serving food. Boo.
author: Matt E.

description:
*This review is for their happy hour only*

If you're looking for a spot with good vibes, good drinks, and delicious snacks, you better come check this place out for happy hour. HH is Monday through Friday from 5:00pm-7:00pm.

My favorite drink on their HH menu is the $7 "Lao-Jito" (Absolut Vodka + Cucumber + Basil + Lime Soda). I'm normally not a big fan of vodka (in particular Absolut...), but they honestly do a great job of making this drink. If you're looking for something sweet, slightly sour, and strong (without tasting strong at all) - I highly recommend giving this a try. 

Snacks wise, their $8 "Garlic Chicken Wings" (comes in 6 pieces) is bomb.com. My friends and I started off with 2 plates of chicken... and ended up ordering 6. It's that juicy and amazing. 

And if you're a potato lover like me, don't forget the $6 "Tom-Yum French Fries". The kick of Tom Yum really enhances the flavor of the fries!
author: Cindy L.

description:
I am always looking for something delicious yet different. The food is amazing: we had a garden fish - the presentation and quality were amazing. Definitely more than enough food for two people.
Their desserts looked really good and Mango one seems to be very popular but we decided to try something different and ordered chocolate soufflé: it consisted of a warm chocolate cake, some tea ice cream and fruit. Yummy!!
Everyone's food looked very tempting so I am considering going back there in the nearest future.
author: Irina R.

description: Hit and miss, some of the food was great some of it wasn't. Drinks weren't but crab curry was delish.  Steak wasn't good but the dessert in the coconut was amazing! So I donno, I guess if you know what to order it'd be a five star. But because there were so many misses it's gonna be half.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Easy to get a table for 2 on a Saturday night.
Got the Larb Zeen Beef Lettuce Wrap and Lao Fried Rice to share. There was so much food there was enough for lunch the next day. Everything was really delicious, but be warned it is pretty spicy--consider cooling down with a Thai Iced Tea.

Prices were fair and we liked the general ambience and decor of the place: swanky hotel with asian influences.
author: Lucy L.

description:
$21 for pho LOL. Do I really need to say any more than that?

But really. Lao Table is at a great spot as it is surrounded by a ton of businesses, so I'm sure they get a good amount of people not caring about money and expensing their meals here. And don't get me wrong, the food is realllyyy good. The wings were bomb, the beef cube appetizer was tender and tasty, the minced chicken was a perfect blend of sweet and spicy, and the pho tasted like pho (lol).

However, be ready to spend $$$$ because it is definitely not your typical thai/lao food prices. The prices alone is the only reason why I wouldn't come back, especially because I love their open space and high ceilings.
author: Elvi T.

description:
I would eat the eggplant tofu dish every day. It's legit.
Their service is a bit off -- host was all over the place, lost on the whole reservation tablet, and then the server lagged getting our order even though we were one of the first tables there for lunch. 
Note: there is not a lunch menu. It's one menu, so prices can be hefty for lunch. And be up for sharing, because it's all dinner platters.
author: Amy O.

description:
We were wowed by the experience here. It was a Friday night and we were looking for a place to eat in our new neighborhood. When we passed by this restaurant, we were surprised by the number of people eating inside. We checked out another place but ultimately decided to come back here for some Laotian food. 

We were greeted and promptly seated. The space is beautifully decorated with high ceilings and top 40s music, giving it a trendy / modern feel. Lots of people at the bar presumably for HH. We shared the wrapping vegetable crispy rolls, which you assemble yourself (similar to lettuce wraps) but better! We also got a bowl of the tom-zaab beef which was delicious. Really tender beef similar to tom-yum but had more of a sour profile. We also got the crispy sticky rice salad with fermented pork sausage. Everything was delicious and we were definitely full after sharing these 3 dishes. We decided to peek at the dessert menu and couldn't resist the coconut sticky rice option. It was a coconut filled with coconut ice cream (with chunks of coconut) and 2 chunks of sticky rice wrapped and steamed in banana leaf. 

Overall, this was definitely one of the best more memorable meals we've had in a while. $100+ for 2 people with drinks. The only thing that wasn't really memorable were the cocktails. Next time will opt for a beer or a glass of sparkling wine to cut some of the spiciness. 

Can't wait to come back and try out some of the other items on the menu.
author: Yin H.

description:
Lao Table is absolutely authentic and delicious! This is hands down, my go-to place for Laotian food on the SF bay area. It's amongst my top 3 favorite Lao restaurants in the world outside of Laos (Lao Cafe in London and Khe-yo in NYC are my other two favorites).

All the dishes have unique, distinct flavors. My favorite item on the menu was the fish garden. It comes with a deep fried fish, cucumber salad with all the yummy fishy sauce, the absolute BEST beef jerky ever, chicken skewers, sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves, noodles and an herb salad. Although it was $70 for this dish, we shared it amongst a group of 6 people -- definitely meant to be shared.

For smaller dishes/smaller parties, I'd high recommend the Crispy Sticky Rice Salad (traditionally called Nam Kao). The crispy fried rice is prepared with fermented pork. There is abundance of greens/herbs so make it into a lettuce wrap and eat with your hands.

The Zeen Ping (hanger steak) is also highly recommended. It was tender and cooked to perfection. It comes with a chili lime dipping sauce which is very authentic -- although I'd like it to be spicier.

The service is also impeccable. The servers are extremely nice, attentive, and knows the menu well. That's always a good sign since the staff eats the food. The restaurant is clean and has a nice ambiance. Parking sucks, but applies to all of SF. 

Happy eating!
author: Mee V.

description:
Amazing food, service, aesthetics and ambience!! Made a reservation for dinner. This place is also great for small or large groups. There needs to be more places like this in SF that have it all! 

Made a reservation and came for dinner. We got:

- Thai Ice Tea 
- Lao Fried Rice Vegetarian
- Spicy Eggplant
- Chocolate Souffle with Thai Tea Ice Cream
author: Divya A.

description: Duuuuuuude. This place was a major disappointment. I ordered on Yelp. Food arrived 2 hours later. I'd ordered fresh spring rolls, extra peanut sauce+basil eggplant, chicken satay, extra peanut sauce. I got no extra peanut sauce for one dish, none for the other, overly fried/hard tofu in the eggplant dish, and greasy a** chicken, favorless and gummy. Noooooooo thank you!
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Came here twice...it's just ok.

First time I had the salmon because they were out of sea bass. It was good!

Second time I had the sea bass...it was not what I expected but still good.

My stomach rumbled a lot after my first time here but I still came back to try the sea bass.

The place is pricey. I rather it be Thai OSHA with the Thai dishes. I liked it better when it was that. 

I also got to taste my friends garlic pork. That was super good!
author: Kat D.

description: Cocktail hour is 4:30-6 Monday through Friday during the summer. I highly suggest you go for drinks, oysters, and great chicken wings with garlic. Everything here is so tasty. I've already suggested this place to friends. The cucumber cocktails are so refreshing!
author: Morgan D.

description: The food is good here but I don't love the atmosphere. It's great for some people but not for me. Kinda fluorescent, very sterile. Like a hotel kind of. It's very off-putting and feels very artificial.
author: Neil S.

description:
True rating is 3.5

I came here for dinner on a Friday, environment is pretty nice, dim lights and modern feel. Service was great. This place is owned by Osha Thai, but it's a bit different, cause it has a mix of Laotian taste to the menu.

We ordered:
Tom Kha: I really liked this, they had pineapples in the soup which at first I was like whaaa, but it went super well! I would definitely get this again.
Sticky Rice Salad: This was decent, sticky rice with lettuce crap, its kind of spicy so if you are not a fan of spices I wouldn't order this
Red Curry: Pretty good, the curry tasted authentic and had good flavor. Came with rice and noodles!
Pad Mee Prawns: Pass, the noodles were dry, not much flavor and it was just spicy. 

Overall, this place is not the best, but it isn't bad. I feel it is a great place for group dinners and its a relaxing environment. I would say the authenticity is better than Osha Thai.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Absolutely delicious desserts and wonderful ambiance. The lamb curry is definitely worth trying.

The Thai tea is overpriced.  Tempting to dock one star off this review for the prices; however, the food is quite good so it's mostly worth it.

My favorite dish was the Lao Sausage.  It was so good!

The desserts are the highlight.  The coconut and shaved mango ice are worth it.
author: Chris R.

description:
Do yourself a favor and stop by this place when in the area, your tastebuds will thank you for taking them on an epic journey.

I coincidentally stumbled upon this place on a Tuesday night because I was at a nearby bar (Natoma Cabana) with sis & her bf and we were looking for walking distance food.

Walked in and we were seated right away - granted it was not that busy. Ordered a Pineapple Millionaire Cocktail (served in a big pineapple cup) for the table to share. Though it was too good to be sharing with others, snag your own if you can. 

We all were super hungry so we ordered a good amount of food: Pineapple Fried Rice, Veggie Crispy Rolls, Mixed Vegetable Wok,  
Suae Hong Hai (Crying Tiger Steak) - which comes w/side of sticky rice, and totally prawns... Yes I know we ordered a lot for 3 people. But I'm glad we did - just shared everything! The food was so tasty and seasoned so well. My favorite dish was the Mixed Vegetable Wok with the pieces of tofu and the veggie crispy rolls. Never tried Laotian food before and this was awesome first experience! :) I'll be bringing more people back here.
author: Joscelynne R.

description:
I'd give this one 3.5 stars if I could. I love the atmosphere and that I can get a reservation on Yelp super easily, even for a time-slot during the crazy lunch rush. The food is good, but I've never been wowed by anything, especially given the price tag that accompanies the food. Service also tends to be on the slower side, which is something to keep in mind when you're trying to dine within the lunch hour. 

My lunch buddy and I shared the foie gras appetizer, which was expertly presented with a tall glass cover (see pics) lifted up into the air, both for the dramatic reveal and for wafting the fatty delicious smells toward our noses. Flavor was ok, but not super memorable. 

The basics tend to be solid (pad thai, basil chicken, thai ice tea and Vietnamese coffee). Those drinks also come with a fun preparation at the table.

I really enjoyed my pineapple fried rice with chicken and prawns. I had plenty of leftovers for the next day, but ultimately didn't find it worth $18. My local neighborhood chinese place has the same dish at half the price.
author: Nikki M.

description:
I had been to Osha Thai when it was in this location but haven't been since they did the transformation.  After eating here I'm not sure why I haven't though as it is a great restaurant.  We had a team work event here and we were seated at the longest table I think I have ever been at.

To begin you need to order one of their fancy drinks.  I got the Millionaire's Pineapple and the presentation alone was amazing.  The copper pineapple mug weighed about 5 pounds.

We had a variety of appetizers pre set including the spring rolls and calamari.  For my main meal I continued with the pineapple theme and got the pineapple fried rice which was really good.

There is a reason this place is so packed all the time because of the great food!
author: Blake B.

description:
This review is for taking out only! 

I really like this spot for Laotian/Thai food! I decided to place an order for pick-up today through the yelp app and ordering was fairly simple. Huge variety and I'm a fan of this cuisine! 

Opted for the basil chicken! Keep in mind this comes with a fried egg and rice. Huge portions and enough for 2 meals! Pick up was fairly easy too. I got here earlier than the pickup time and food was ready. 

Onto the food... pretty darn good! I really like basil chicken and this one didn't disappoint. Loads of flavor and spices :)

Pretty pricy but the amount of food you get is reasonable. I will be back to try other items!
author: Elaine C.

description:
So many different places to try in San Francisco, but for sure if you are in the financial district area, a must try is Lao Table. My husband is Laotian so I am spoiled with really good home cooked dishes from my MIL, but when the craving hits when I am traveling, it's been tough to find a decent restaurant that serves authentic Lao style dishes on the road. 

Low and behold, I found Lao Table! I got a taste last year when I was in town on a girls trip but it was only leftovers so I knew I needed to be there in person and eat the food fresh.  

I arrived right after opening and was seated right away at the bar. You know a place is good when it's a Wednesday night and the place is packed within an hour of opening.  They do have Happy Hour specials so take advantage of those if you want.

I was super hungry so I started off with the garlic chicken wings off the Happy Hour menu (this menu is not up on their website). I love my garlic so fried garlic on top of crispy wings that are hot and fresh was delish! I gobbled these up in no time.

For dinner, I ordered the Suae Hong Hai (Crying Tiger Steak). This comes with a side of sticky rice and dipping sauce called Jaow. The meat was so tender and so buttery and so worth the $34.95 for the dish. The sticky rice was a bit mushy for my taste but still good. I ordered a side of Papaya Salad with medium spice to go with it and it reminded me of my MIL's for sure. The right amount of sour and sweet and it was hard to stop eating.

I didn't stop there, like I said, I was super hungry!  I ordered the mango shaved ice with a thai tea. It was a great sweet ending to the meal. Good thing I walked because I needed the 10 minute walk back to my hotel to help me digest!

When I left about an hour later, the restaurant was packed and for good reason. Good drinks and food make this place a legit Lao style restaurant. A definite must stop if you want to try a new kind of place. I recommend asking about the authentic Lao dishes to try. There are some regular dishes like the fried rice that I'd probably stay away from and stick with the authentic dishes because you will for sure be in for a happy surprise.
author: Aimee N.

description: One of the good places in the city for Thai food. Prices are slightly on the higher side, but the quality and quantity of the food is good for those prices. I like their fried rice, red curry and panang curry. If you are going with a large group, it is better to make a reservation as the place is always busy.
author: Supraja Y.

description:
Been here a couple times.  It's a fun place with good traditional Laotian food.  You'll find nam kao (crispy rice with fermented raw pork), papaya salad, sausage, jeow.  It's great if you like eating wrapping your food with veggies (lettuce, cabbage) and eat with your fingers.  Tried both the whole fish and the tomahawk steak.  Not worth a repeat but good to try.  They do their best to service you.  The tomahawk was over cooked and they fixed it.  

If I wasn't in SF, I would not make a special trip for this place but would take guests to this place if they wanted Laotian food.
author: Lynn V.

description:
I've been to Laos, so I was excited to try Lao Table to bring me back to my vacay. 

Food here was good, ambiance was bougie (which is not like Laos at all), but it was pricey (of course being in FiDi) and the service was TERRIBLE. 

I accidentally dropped a bean sprout in my water, so I asked a waitress if I could have another glass. 
10 minutes passed, I asked someone else. 
10 minutes passed, I asked the first waitress.
10 minutes passed. OK I GUESS I'LL JUST DRINK THIS BEAN SPROUT WATER.

Food wise, the kurobuta pork belly was AMAZING though (5 stars, $26). So bomb, five spice kurobuta pork belly had so much flavor and rice and pickled cabbage complimented it. It's a must order. 

Other good orders:  Me Ka Ti (3.5 stars, $19) and the papaya salad (3.5 stars, $22) 

Good thing your food tastes good Lao Table.. I almost flipped the table. Please hydrate your customers. Thank you.
author: Raquel Y.

description: Came here to hang out and spend time with my best friends. They gave us amazing service and personable care and attention. Couldn't recommend this restaurant more!
author: Athawat K.

description:
This is basically OSHA in disguise with a few changes on the menu. The place still looks the same. The chef is still the same. And some part of the food menu changed, for the worse. 

We ordered the curry crab noodles. The curry was decent but the noodles were completely over cooked with super soggy carrot. Not even worth $10, never mind the $29 price tag. 

The spicy eggplant was super oily - will give you a stomachache if you dare to finish. It reminds of Americanized Chinese food that I have successfully avoided in SF so far but was forced to relive again here. 

The crispy spring roll was ok but not great. The sweet and sour sauce is too sweet. 

If you end up here, order the basic OSHA dishes - Thai fried rice, Thai soups, etc.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Definitely a cute location, a beautiful design, and tasty food. I struggle at times with high-end Asian food, as some of the best Thai, Cambodian, Vietnamese food I'd had has been hole-in-the-wall and cash only. 

But my friends and I popped in after the auto show, had a delightful meal... which was a little spendy, likely because it's San Francisco and the owners are likely being charged $80K per month for the space.

Definitely worth checking out, it's tasty and the Lao steak (I forget the proper name) I had was one of the best steaks of my life.
author: Sean B.

description:
Should be $$$ in terms of price. (Yelp has this as $$ as I write this.) 

Why? Dinner for two is $60, without drinks, appetizer, or dessert. Duck curry -- a pretty simple dish -- is $24. Herbal tea, $7.50. You get the picture. 

That said, the service is quick and friendly, and the food is good.
author: Al S.

description:
Was initially turned off by the high prices on this menu (most entrees $20+), but I have to concede that the food is pretty good. 

My friend and I ordered the duck wings appetizer and pad pha beef. The duck wings were delicious, crispy on the outside with a sweet glaze, and tender on the inside. The beef was surprisingly spicy, and I actually had to eat some rice to tamp down the fire in my mouth. 

The portion sizes are good, so between my friend and I, we got full off of the appetizer and entree we ordered. The restaurant also filled up pretty quickly around 7pm, so try to arrive before then.
author: Sophie W.

description:
We come here a lot for team lunches. They used to be really slow lol but have gotten a lot better.

The basil chicken has been my favorite order so far. I've gotten their style of pad thai before and it was pretty good too. 

The Vietnamese coffee is crazy sweet - sweetened before the condensed milk is added even. 

Really nice plating and decor.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Overall: Dined at Lao Table for lunch with coworkers. All had various dietary needs and Lao Table met them all. Along with their impeccable service they also have many quality dining options to meet all of our dietary needs. This is definitely a place you want to try.

Service: 5 stars - We made a reservation but our group had to add another 3-4 people and Lao Table was quick to accommodate and seat us quickly. They happily provided food recommendations and made us feel very welcome.

Food & Drinks: 4 stars - I had the Crying river steak and it was delicious cooked perfectly medium. Decided to order a Pineapple Millionaire cocktail. Its a must do! Not too sweet and served in a pineapple copper glass.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I came with a large group of people. We were seated very quickly with no reservation (big plus), but our food didn't come out very quickly -- and more importantly, it didn't come out together. The appetizers came together with the first entrees, which was kind of odd. My friend's salad didn't come until about 20 minutes after the rest of the food... I mean, how could a salad take so much longer to make? (I wonder if they had simply forgotten it. It took about 5 minutes after we flagged down a server.)

I could forgive this had the food been fantastic... but it was only decent. The grilled calamari ($15) was great, albeit somewhat difficult to share, but the honey roasted duck (Khao Nar Ped, $23) that I got was only alright, and in my opinion not worth the somewhat hefty price.
author: Yves L.

description:
If I had to go back to one of the restaurants on my recent visit to San Francisco, this would be it. The food is inventive, beautiful, fresh, delicious and healthy! 

The restaurant is in a borderline sketchy neighborhood, particularly at night, but well worth the trek. As the night wore on, there definitely were some interesting individuals at the bar! 

The fresh coconut was a delicious and refreshing drink, the grilled calamari was grilled to perfection. The Miang Pla blew us both away, it was so simple, yet so impressive at the same time. I cannot stress how much, that if you do visit you need to do the Miang Pla. 

I've never been a huge fan of ordering lettuce wraps at a restaurant, they seem so boring and overpriced for what they are. The Miang Pla here changed my mind. It wasn't the Americanized lettuce wraps you get at chains that are over sauced, but rather these rely on fresh herbs and textures with a little sauce. 

I could eat Miang Pla all day long! This will be my first stop when I come back to San Francisco. The inside of the restaurant is really pretty as well!
author: Mary P.

description:
Went here on a weekday for lunch. It's a pretty nice, fine dining type place. There wasn't any wait and we got a table right away!

I got the chicken satay and vegetarian khaw kai noodles. I am mostly vegetarian with chicken satay being one of my few exceptions - it did not disappoint. The peanut sauce that came with it was amazing as well.

The noodleswere pretty good. It was a large portion and had to take some to go. The spices were mild but could've been much better. The noddle itself and the veggies were well done and the white bean sprout thing went pretty well with them.

Overall, a pretty solid meal. A bit on the pricier side given the nice ambience!
author: Vignesh B.

description: Popped in for lunch today while visiting SF and was very impressed. Wide-ranging menu makes it a good option for groups with varying preferences - I noticed there are a lot of vegetarian/vegan options as well. Service was very speedy - I sat in the bar and had placed my order and received my food in under 10 minutes, even though the place was quite busy. The presentation of the food is also beautiful, making it a great spot for a business lunch, or if you want to impress a date at a reasonable price point!
author: Halle H.

description:
I work in SoMa and always wanted to try this place. Had an art show to attend at 111 Minna across the street and figured, what a better time to try it.

Interior is super cute and modern. Clean, too. The bathroom was my favorite part LOL, and the restaurant is decked out with orchids. 

Ordered the pineapple fried rice and the pad moo-pa (Kurobuta "Black Hog" pork shoulder). Both were mouth. watering. and they balanced each other out, as the pineapple fried rice served as more as a side for us. The pork was served with rice too so we were carbed out. There was even enough leftover for a second meal.

Highly recommend. Will be back!!!!
author: Genevieve M.

description: Presentation is KEY! They got that right at this place is SOMA. Came here for a late birthday and they totally made it special =) Definitely get the drink in the copper pineapple, spring rolls, Basil Chicken and Pineapple Fried Rice!
author: Ceci B.

description:
Excellent food, even better service!

Ethnic food with an air of elegance, would definitely recommend Lap Table to all my friends.

The service staff are bar none, always polite and respectful! 

I'll be coming back here soon!
author: Arvind M.

description: Food is good! Portion is seemingly small though. The place is also a little noisy and crowded, since it is popular.
author: Di F.

description: Pretty good and creative Thai food overall. The spring roll was ok, but it a nice try to change traditional Thai spring roll. Oysters is a good deal when I went there, maybe more fresh will be better. The tiger cry steak is AMAZING.   Recommend! Juicy and tender, the beef itself is really good quality. The flavor of the seasonings and sauce is good pare with steak. Maybe sticky rice is not a good side though.
author: Jiaė W.

description:
The music gets louder as it gets later into the evening, but it was already pretty loud when we got seated @630 pm on a weekday (lol). I'm not a grandma by any means but I'd rather go to a club when I wanna go to a club instead of have a dining experience @ a club noise level. 

Portions are large and prices are higher than the norm for this type of food in SF, so definitely share things and try more options! We had the veggie spring rolls, crispy rice salad and the pad mee lao (prawn noodles w/ egg). 

The servers have matching color palette attire and introduce each dish with how it should be eaten, which is a cute touch -- feels kind of like a themed dining experience especially w/ the ambiance.
author: Hana S.

description: First time here and Foods was so good! And nice services! Definitely will comeback more often
author: Tram N.

description:
At this place I tried the best Mai Thai ever!!! And the best calamari ( you can find it at appetizers).
You have to wait long for it oder, but it worth it!!@
author: Irishka M.

description:
I learned Lao Table is also owned by Osha Thai--no wonder I felt like I've been there before upon walking in. Same atmosphere as Osha Thai. I've been here on two occasions now & I don't think I've had any dish I've disliked thus far. In true FOMO fashion, I like to go with people who like to over-order so I can try a bit of everything. As they say, the more food, the merrier (jk, that's not really a saying...).

Would order again:
- Vegetarian Crispy Rolls -- delicious veggie egg rolls--ordered this twice.
- Tom En Keow -- coconut milk soup with beef.
- Spicy Eggplant -- I love eggplant & tofu.
- Khaw Kai Noodles -- wok-fried thick rice noodles with chicken.
- Pad Mee Prawns -- stir-fried thin rice noodles.
- Thai Tea -- a little sweet, but still good.

Would skip unless it's within your preference:
- Om Chicken Curry -- spicy chicken clear curry--bf liked this, but I thought it was kind of bland.
- Mark Mango -- mango sticky rice with cream of coconut & mango icy--LOL I ordered this without knowing how big it was going to be. IT'S HUGE.
- Lao Soda -- good amount of alcohol in this!

I've been here for lunch & dinner, both times with reservations. They get really busy at lunch! Loved the interior decor, especially during dinner because they turn the purple & pink lights on (pink is my favorite color).

Overall, wouldn't hesitate to come back here!
author: Carol N.

description: Came here on a Friday for lunch at 11:45am and finished at about 12:45pm. We ordered the fried pork belly, khaw kai noodles, and the crispy sticky rice salad. Everything was sooo good! The presentation was also nice and I liked their plates. Their desserts look insane! I'll be back.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I have never tried Laotian food before, so I was thrilled to have a work lunch at Lao Table in the FiDi with my colleague! 

I've tried Thai, Burmese; and Cambodian food before so I was very curious what Laotian food would taste like.

My overall impression from Lao Table was that Laotian food was sweeter and of a chewier / rice-ier texture than Thai food.

Lao Table has contemporary decor, and servers are attentive, and the tables are close together. 

I tried the Spring Rolls, Khaw Kai Noodles, and the Thai Iced Tea. Delicious! My only reservation was that the Thai Iced Tea was made of crushed ice, I prefer it on the rocks.

If you are looking for an alternative to SE Asian food and want to try something different, I highly recommend Lao Table and hope to be back again someday.
author: Christie S.

description: It's an okay place. Not much to say, they beat the gong if someone celebrates Bday. Service is meh with good looking Asian implants. Communication was a bit of a problem...Even though $$ this place is pricey. Calamary and cocktails were good, but once the food was cold wasn't edible.
author: Ian P.

description:
This place has not disappointed yet! Recently came here for a birthday lunch with coworkers. We made a note on our reservation that we were a bit rushed because we had a meeting. Our food came out promptly with plenty of time to spare to socialize.

Our table of 6 ordered so much food, but it was all delish! 

- Crispy Spring Rolls
- Vegetarian Spicy Eggplant
- Vegetarian Red Curry
- Basil Chicken
- Pad Mee Lao Prawns Noodle
- Kurobuta Pork Belly
- Vegetarian Fried Rice
 
One other item I love there that we did not order is the Crispy Sticky Rice Salad.

Authentic flavors, fresh vegetables, elegantly prepared and plated, and so good I ate the leftovers for the next two days.

It is not the cheapest, but a great restaurant to splurge on once in a while. I promise it's worth it.
author: My N.

description:
Lao Table is a more upscale dining spot for generally authentically tasting Southeast Asian food. It's on the pricier and fancier end, but the taste matches up! I'm not one to speak for how traditionally prepared the food is but it did satisfy my Asian taste buds.

This place is decorated nicely like a nice romantic dinner spot. It's really spacious, theres sky high ceilings and plenty of tables for walk in. They have reservations on Yelp if you want to book a table though.

The server greeted us with lemongrass towels that are water activated, which was a nice touch. They were really attentive, so that was great considering a lot of Thai restaurants I go to are really slow. Food came out lightning fast and I wonder how they pulled that off.

If you're willing to foot a $20-25+ for a Laotian/Thai entree, want nice ambiance and want to treat yourself to something nice this is a good spot. There's salads, soups, wok dishes, noodles, rice dishes, curries and grilled/steamed options to choose from. They have vegetarian options! The grilled/steamed section is $30+ so I avoided that section. It was fairly easy to stick to something under $25.

Portions are generous and they come in big family style bowls. The noodles can easily be shared between two people from the looks of it. 

Mixed Vegetables - Wok fried farmer market vegetable + tofu + mushroom w/oyster sauce. For such a simple dish, they really did a good job with this! The sauce was light and had great flavor. The veggies were fresh and crunchy! There was a lot to go around. It comes with jasmine rice which comes in a small bowl which is the perfect size for me. The ratio of veggies and tofu to rice was ideal. I get this dish at many Thai places and this one particularly stood out to me which is a good sign. It ran for $14 on the menu so this is one of the more affordable and healthier options.

I tried some of the Totally Prawns curry and was very pleased with how it tasted! The curry is rich in flavor and the prawns looked very large and juicy.

For Asian food, this is generally an expensive spot to go to and not a place I would frequent. However, it's a great restaurant in my opinion for times you want to treat yourself.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Came here on a whim when our napa trip was cut short, thanks to my yelp research we found a great spot! It's a large place, a little dark, and gets very crowded but the tables are spaced far enough apart that you don't feel cramped. The food was great!

We started with two orders of the crispy spring rolls which were great as was the dipping sauce - pretty classic but always one of my favorites, they didn't disappoint! For dinner my fiancée and I shared the khaw kai noodles (similar to a more soy-based pad Thai) and the Lao fried rice which comes with 3 chicken wings. Both were AMAZING and we left absolutely stuffed to the brim, love me some asian food. Others at the table got pho duck (which he raved about) and the basil chicken which I didn't try but looked just as good (photo below). 

All in all, a good night out atmosphere with awesome food and quick service - great for a more upscale asian dinner out! Loved it!
author: Shaina F.

description:
Too expensive for that simple food nothing special .
Also with the waiter forgot our food that we had ordered .We had to wait for a long time to get food because he forgot to put our order .
author: Rock L.

description: Came for happy hour on a weekday. Although I had reservations, they let us sit at the bar. I was enticed by the $1 oysters, but I don't think I would do it again. Maybe just personal preference though... We ordered some wine off of the happy hour menu and 2 main dishes as well. Everything was mediocre, but not horrible. Nothing to write home about and don't think I would choose to go back again unless it was convenient.
author: Megan K.

description: We ordered the beef Saland, it was too Salty and the meat was so dry. We payed about $26 for a bowl of beef pho. Meat was dry, the soup was not hot. It is over price and not worth it. This place was not busy.Everyone was busy dressed up the tables but no one help take our empty dishes away. We had waited for a long time to get our food. If you just look for presentation this place will be good for you. For the taste not recommend at all!
author: Snow H.

description:
My friends and I are visiting from out of town. We came here because we saw all of the great reviews on Yelp and wanted to try something different, and none of us had ever been to a Laotian restaurant before (but we've had home made Laos food). First off, the interior design is beautiful! We were greeted promptly at the host station, but after that - it was down hill from there. 

After we were asked how many people were in our lunch group, we were seated shortly afterwards, but NO ONE came to check on us. My friend asked twice if we had a server and when another employee asked our server to come see us, he rolled his eyes at them. Our server barely greeted us or asked us if we had any questions or anything. This was our first time at a Laos restaurant, and having a server informing us about the menu would have been nice.

When our food came out, it was brought to us by someone else besides our server, and not once did anyone come to check on us. Luckily, the food was good, but in my opinion - extremely overpriced.

The bill was about $75 for one entree, a beer, and two appetizers. Also, I ordered the cup of Tom yum soup but their server put in the bowl (cup is $8 and bowl is $19). I didn't realize what I got was the bowl until after I saw the bill. I didn't realize what I received was the bowl because it seemed pretty small. But I didn't complain since we finished it all. 

Needless to say, I don't think I'd ever come here again nor would I recommend this place. Yes, the food is good, but not worth the price. Any mediocre Thai restaurant would suffice for a fraction of the price.

This was also a disappointing experience considering this was the very first place we visited during our San Francisco trip. :(

I'm giving this place a two star for the horrible service and pricey food. I will say that their Tom Yum was very good and so was the beef stick we ordered just in case anyone needed help deciding on what to order.
author: Cery K.

description:
Awesome and really impressive. If you're really into instagramming your food, this is the place to go right now!

What I would recommend:
* Pineapple Millionaire - I love this drink! Served in a nice pineapple copper-looking cup, this drink is so dangerous. You can't even taste the alcohol and you'll probably be asking for more!
* Happy Hour: Come for the $1 oysters, worth it.
* The Desserts! So good.

I got to try multiple dishes here and some of them were outstanding. However, for the price, you may except a little bit more. For example, the pineapple fried rice for $17 only came with 2 prawns - you do get a good amount chicken though. The Totally Prawns plate was recommended to us by the staff twice, and we don't think it was the best dish there... Plus, you don't get that many "prawns." I would stick with the meats in the "steam-charcoal-grill" section.

I would recommend ordering family style if you're in a big group as most dishes are in the $20-$30 ballpark. Portions are relatively generous but still a little pricey. Staff is nice and helpful and presentation is done beautifully -worth the instagram/snapchat shots to your friends!
author: Alex L.

description:
