Amazing Thai restaurant, the dishes are so good beautiful pretty and very tasty! the desert coconut ice cream so yummy 
There are many fusion restaurants that the food is too far from reality but not Lao I love this place
author: Avi E.

description:
First of all, I am so glad there an opportunity here for FIDI workers to experience Lao food. 
I have been here twice, and both times I ordered thum mak hoong. Both times they gave me Thai style, no crab, no padaek. Makes me wonder if they still serve it authentic style, or if there has been a miscommunication between the kitchen staff? I looked at all the "thum mak hoong" photos from 2018 and they don't look crabby at all! What happened!? Also ordered the sai oua (Lao sausage), served more like Thai style with peanut and ginger. It was not spicy, but it wasn't bad. All in all, everything was just A-OK. Would come back again because it's close to work.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Made a reservation online here for 2 people for lunch on Friday and we were seated immediately. The waitress promptly came to take our drink order and we were given time to pursue through the menu. 

I ordered the Pad Mee Lao w/ prawns and our food came out pretty quickly given how busy it was getting for the lunch time rush. There was surprisingly a generous serving of prawns which is pretty rare and just a generous portion size in general! I had eaten about 40% of my plate and was stuffed and had to take the rest home. It was pretty good and the prawns were very fresh which I enjoyed! 

It is pretty pricey as it is a pretty standard dish ($17.95 before tax and tip) - but given the generous portion size + generous prawn/noodle ratio I would say its pretty fair! 

Will definitely be back and try something else next time! 

PROS:
- Super insta-worthy food presentation + interior + ambience 
- Generous food serving and portion
- Wide variety of food on menu 
- Friendly and efficient service
author: Sarah H.

description:
Missed our reservation, but was able to get seated relatively quickly. 

Food: overall quality was great. Some of the dishes were underwhelming or overpriced. Khao mun gai was essentially a Hainese chicken dish. Khao Poon crab curry was delicious, but there was literally a very small bunch of rice noodles, very little crab meat and the rest was just a giant plate of vegetables.  Will definitely be hungry if this is all you're having. 

I initially thought the mango sticky rice was just going to be mango and sticky rice, but it also came with a huge side of shaved ice. The sticky rice with coconut sauce was on point. Also ordered the Thai tea jumbo icy before we realized how giant the mango sticky rice was. Jumbo icy was not worth it. Besides the fruit on top, it was just a giant bowl of shaved ice with Thai tea poured over it. Fruit to ice ratio was very uneven. Probably not worth the $20.
author: Kacey S.

description:
I am so glad I finally got to check out this place with one of my good friends visiting from Canada. It's a nice swanky place and conveniently located near financial district. On a normal basis, I wouldn't be coming here every day, because it will just sink a hole in my pocket. Other than that, they have an eclectic menu, which had some of them included German sausage? 

Spiciness note: You need to tell them to go down on the spiciness scale if you can't take the heat. We ordered the Lao Papaya Salad in mild heat and it was still spicy. My German friend and I had to drink a few glasses of cold water with rice to make ourselves stop crying. At least it was good we thought.
author: Moua L.

description:
Great food and super nice vibe. Lao Table offers a great dinner spot for friends and family get together. The location is very accessible from Montgomery BART station - about five minutes walk. Decor is nice and is fairly crowded but not to the extent that you would give up waiting right away. If you come in a larger group, better reserve with Yelp first. 

The food is beautifully presented and delicious. I am not sure how much percent is really authentic Laotian food but the food definitely stands out from other mediocre Thai restaurants. The calamari is tender and flavorful. Pork neck salad is spiceful and pork neck is super tender, full of umami and juicy. The duck rice is decent - though the portion is a little bit small and it doesn't come with many pieces of duck meat. The highlight is definitely the dessert - coconut ice cream in a young coconut with banana leaf wrapped sweet sticky rice. The hot sweet sticky rice blends so well with the cold and refreshing coconut ice cream - perfect combination. The portion HUGE with the entire coconut stuffed with rich ice cream. Don't forget to scrap the wall of the young coconut to get the tender coconut meat. The light but refreshing taste of it balances perfectly with the sweet sticky rice and the ice cream. The dessert itself definitely bumped the overall rating fr 3.5 to 4.

The service is also decent and responsive and servers are all very nice and considerate. Definitely will come back for another meal if I'm in the area!
author: Shen Q.

description:
I wasn't quite as impressed with Lao Table as some of my dining partners. Perhaps it was because there are so many amazing Thai restaurants in SF. Or because there are so many amazing eateries just in the SoMa district alone. Or maybe it was just an off day for me. Whatever the case, it was a good meal and one I enjoyed, but not the best when I consider all that stiff competition. 

I'll second many a previous reviewer by saying the place is beautiful inside. If there is one thing they have going better than any other Thai place I've been to, it's a sense of classy ambiance. When it came to the food, however, I was left wanting more. The calamari was literally a whole squid chopped up. While that may be exactly how it is supposed to be served (as opposed to the Americanized, deep-fried beyond recognition version) it didn't do much for me in the flavor department. I also couldn't help but long for many a previous Pho experience while eating their version. It lacked most of the fresh veggie sides I've grown accustomed to elsewhere and was served a little less hot than I would have liked. 

Again, nothing was bad here and I'm sure I'll return for another meal. It's a nice atmosphere for food or drinks.
author: Alex L.

description:
Nice spot for Laotian / Thai style food for dinner in the SOMA / fidi area. I've never had Laotian food before so I don't have a base line to compare it to. 

I dined here with my friend who was vegetarian, so we were limited as to what we could order to share, however I was pleasantly surprised by the menu that specified dishes that had a 'vegetarian option' available. This was helpful for us to easily identify what we could order without having to read through the ingredients in each item. 

We ordered the spring rolls (vegetarian style) to share and it came with tofu as the substitute.The outside layer of the spring roll was a bit thicker than your average spring roll wrapper - it tasted more like a rice noodle wrapper. Still good, but a bit thick if you're trying to cut back on carbs like me. 

I also ordered the papaya salad. I love the freshness of ripe papaya salad, however it was so incredibly spicy, I could not even eat my dish. The small salad came on a large plate with a side of noodles, lettuce wraps, 1 spring roll and fried roll cut in halves. Its hard to rate this dish since I could barely eat the actual papaya salad, but it did look fresh. If you do order this dish, ask for them to hold the spice unless you can handle the heat. 

Overall the service was good, and the ambiance is nice. A good option for large groups too as the restaurant is fairly large.
author: Claire W.

description:
I stopped by Lao Table with a group of colleagues, and OMG, we loved this place. The entire menu was drool-worthy, and when I saw pho on the menu, it was a no-brainer what I would order. I love pho. I might choose it as my last meal. 

A few reasons I enjoyed Lao Table:
+ Beautiful presentation of lunch dishes. I wish I took more photos of the dishes at my table... but trust, it all looked colorful, fresh, and too good to eat.
+ Excellent, friendly, fast service.
+ The interior has a modern, chill vibe.
+ The most beautiful bathrooms I've ever seen. That's a weird thing to say about a bathroom, right? With sleek fixtures and awesome floor-to-ceiling Thai (?) murals, you are a little surprised when you enter. It was confusing but pretty great.
+ Thai Iced Tea! Hooray. It was delicious. Shoutout to my colleagues/friends for encouraging me to try this.

I loved me some Lao and my tummy left feeling very happy with my pho. The broth was flavorful, the portion was super generous, and the meat was juicy and tender. You know your pho is good when you are full but just want to keep sipping the broth uncontrollably. Also, fun facts: you can place a reservation online with them on Yelp AND order pickup through Yelp. Dear lord, if I lived closer, I'd be doing this all the time.
author: Lauren K.

description: Was able to snag a Friday night reservation and I am so glad we did!  This place was such a good surprise - it was a beautiful restaurant and the food was some of the best I have ever eaten.  Had the Pad Pha Beef and Khaw Kai noodles with chicken - sooooo good!  Great service and atmosphere, too!
author: Kristi J.

description:
$100 for Laotian!?!?!!? Isn't that a little much, even in the FiDi...? However, I must say, the food was spectacular.

I think they were a little stingy with the Happy Hour Calamari, but I really liked their Lao-Jito! I probably would've ordered another one if we made it to Happy Hour earlier. But maybe regular-sized Calamari is more worth.

My absolute favorite was the Spicy Steak LAO. It's not spicy at all and the veggies compliment the steak very well. The steak was soft and tender and juicy and gave me warm fuzzies. I like that it comes with a tiny basket of sticky rice - so cute!

The Garlic Pepper Pork Rice Bowl was also good - tasty. But the Larb Zeen Beef Lettuce Wrap was waaaaayyyyyy too spicy for me. I could've even eat another bite of it...

COME HERE FOR YOUR BIRTHDAY AND THEY'LL RING ONE OF THE LARGE BELLS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE RESTAURANT! Super fun. But getting a waitress' attention is kinda like pulling teeth.
author: Athena C.

description:
I picked this place for a lunch meeting with a friend working nearby, and I felt bad right after glancing over the menu with almost every item over $20. I got red curry chicken, and my friend ordered a pork salad. Great food presentation, but the portion was really alright, and the flavor was not impressively different from other restaurants.

The decor was certainly modern and the plating was nice, but the value that went into the food just did not feel quite justified given the high price and okay portion. I wouldn't be surprised how much of the check went to the rent, and for that reason, I would probably skip this one and enjoy a more fulfilling lunch next time somewhere else.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
GET THE PORK KNUCKLE.
Came here a while ago and was pleasantly surprised by Lao Table. Owned by the same people as Osha Thai, I was afraid Lao Table would seem chain-y, but the decorations were cute and the menu had unique items I have not seen elsewhere.
The star of the meal was the pork knuckle. Inspired by a german dish, this pork knuckle was tender and fatty on the inside, but crunchy and flavorful on the outside. I'd highly recommend ordering this with a side of sticky rice and going to town!
The milk tea shaved ice at the end of the meal was only OK, but definitely very tempting to get after watching everyone else get it.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'd give 4-Star on their food. Decent amount and well cooked. I had their papaya salad which is a bit spicy for me but I can live with it. 
Their honesty is 3-Star because they trick you by offering you the $1 oyster and then they told you you can only start with half dozen and once you finish you can order another one. When you finish the first plate they tell you immediately sorry we are running out of oyster! Seriously? Your happy hour is 4-7 and at 5:30 you told us you are running out? Then why do you continue serving oysters to the table next to us who arrive later? Where do those come from???
Plus, it's way too pricey, especially considering the service you get...
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Food is great but had a shit takeout experience where I was asked to wait in an area for my food. Then my food was finished but it wasn't given to me and I ended up waiting longer for no reason. Then I go back to the office to eat my food and my order is wrong. :(

Update:
Ordered takeout here a few more times and the experience was without issue.
author: Dennis C.

description: Food was really good. Service was pretty good too. I came on a busy Friday night, had to sit in the walk way but it wasn't too bad. We the Lao papaya salad, Lao fried rice and the steak. Everything was really good. The dessert was the only thing that was not impressive. We ordered the Mango Mark--something. I wish the sticky rice half of it was larger than the ice. Over all their drinks look great, food and service was not bad. I would come back.
author: Terry G.

description:
I came here for lunch today and instantly saw how packed it was (there was even a small line). I walked up to the hostess and ask for a table of 2, but I was notified that I couldn't be seated until my friend arrived (fine, whatevs). A couple minutes later a huge party of 7 and then a party of 6 came strolling in, and I could tell the hostess was feeling stressed about seating space. A minute or so later, a woman walked in asking how long the wait would be for a party of 2 and the hostess said that unless she had a reservation, Lao Table will not be taking any more walk-ins for the day (...can she do that?). I started to worry if I was even allowed to eat here at this point, because (like the woman) I was also a party of 2 and had no reservation - the only difference was that I walked in 5 minutes earlier than she did.

My friend arrived shortly after and I tapped the hostess that we're ready. I could tell she was hesitant about seating us (really lady? With the reservation crap?), but she begrudgingly led us to the bar with two open stools. Space was cramped - I pretty much sat there with my arms at my sides like a sardine. Food was expensive - most dishes were about $15 but the portions weren't $15 worthy (or even drool worthy). I ordered the spicy eggplant with tofu and it had 0 spice (and minimal flavor). Not impressed.

Overall, it's a pretty lunch spot with some noteworthy decor/ambiance, but unless you're trying to impress a date, I wouldn't bother coming here
author: Rebecca L.

description:
High prices for mediocre food.

Food is all really pricey and it's nothing special from what you'd get anywhere else. Save your money and go anywhere else. 

Think I'd only come here is for their Vege Crispy Rolls on their apps and for the mango sick rice with shaved ice for desserts. I wouldn't come here otherwise.

Crispy rolls were great! Great texture and flavor. Mango sticky rice with shaved ice was great but you're mainly paying for the shaved ice as there's barely any sliced mango or sticky rice.

Staff were mostly nice except for a few exceptions. No less than 5 different staff tried to take our bill which we hadn't touched yet, trying to get us out their empty doors. Second multiple people tried to take our food when we were still working on it.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Let me just say that the food here is INCREDIBLE and deserves 5 stars! Everything we had was delicious but I highly recommend the Crispy Sticky Rice Salad... so bomb! However, be prepared to spend $$$ at this hip restaurant. Good for a date, better with a group of people, but I wouldn't come here on the regular just because it's too pricey for what it is.

The service was not so great. It took forever for someone to come by and get our order, and it wasn't even busy when we got there. There was a waitress standing by the bar doing her makeup... I was hoping she'd look up so I can get her attention, but nope! And when we asked a waitress for to-go boxes, she pointed us to someone else and said "ask your waitress." Thanks but it's not like we hadn't already tried to flag her down.
author: Arielle G.

description:
Wow flavor everywhere here no doubt! Every dish has so much flavor you better be ready for all kinds of spices and not necessarily spicy.

We started with their calamari with rice and it wasn't anything special so wouldn't order that again.

The fried rice was really tasty in flavor and came with an egg on top which is always nice.

They had some very unique peppers in some of the dishes. The Om Chicken came with one that looked like a vine of capers but had a very peppery spice to it and was very spicy. The watermlon eggplant was also a fun ingredient that was pretty much as expected.

The Tom Yum Koong was a bit over concentrated and tasted very salty and sour overall. A small cup is all you need because of how strong it was.

I do recommend the mango shaved ice because they give you a small cup of pure mango. juice to pour over which was really good.

Overall I wouldn't recommend ordering too many creative dishes because you will be overwhelmed with flavors/spices (in case that's not your ideal meal). I'd be back to try other items but only on another special occasion because this place is a bit pricey.
author: Laura Y.

description:
Great food, and thai tea!

Make reservations for lunch for sure.

It is loud inside so if you want a more intimate place to converse I wouldn't recommend this place.

The servers are unfriendly which is why I am taking a star off. None smile nor try to be friendly. I know it is busy and a fast environment but it wouldn't hurt to show appreciation towards your patrons. I said thank you when a server brought my food and she goes "yeah" and walks away.

But the quality of the food is what will keep me coming back.
author: S.J. I.

description:
Came here for a team lunch, and some of the experience was pretty great, and others not so much.  They seemed quite understaffed on their server side, as well as extremely stressed and abrupt with their communication.  Certainly showed that they were trying their best, but they could hire some more folks to speed up the service and follow through (I had to ask for my vietnamese iced coffee to be brought out ~10 minutes after everyone else had received theirs in our party)

Food quantity also varied quite wildly between orders, and my curry tasted and appeared to be more like a broth.  The food tasted good but was certainly not what I expected from a curry.  If they added some more help on the restaurant floor to reduce stress on their staff, and made it more clear (pictures, explanations, or again larger staff with more time to speak to the diners) then it could certainly make it to 4 or possibly stars
author: Matt U.

description:
They advertising happy hours and oysters on signs by the entrance.
If you buy it, they ask you to wait to be sited, then don't bring you the happy hour menu. And if you ask it they'll reply that they actually don't have oysters. Such a shameless marketing
author: Nelly A.

description:
This review is for the food only: Garden Fish was $70 but was perfect for our hungry group of 5 + one more entree (basil chicken) and appetizer (banana blossom salad). Garden fish has all sorts of protein, pickled veggies and sticky rice and noodles for you to wrap in the fresh lettuce, mint & basil. It was really fun to eat with my coworkers. The basil chicken rice was so flavorful. The banana blossom salad was interesting to try but was a little too fiber-y for my taste. The desserts were also beautiful and delicious, but the favorite in our group was the Thai tea ice cream on top of the chocolate soufflé. 

I would definitely come back with my friends.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Pretty plates, great food, slightly slow service, hence the cut in star, but it was a weeknight full of people that just finished a (gaming) conference, so not too upset there. 

We started off with the roasted squid - perfectly cooked, and well seasoned. Comes with tiny pieces of garlic if you feel that the butter from the squid is too much. 

We ordered three entrees: pork belly, noodle dish similar in taste and looks as the pad thai, and the vegetables. Everything was delicious, but I was particularly impressed by the veggies... How often do you get to say that?!

So happy to be adding this restaurant to my neighborhood go-tos!
author: Sung Hee P.

description:
I came during lunch hour so the place was extremely packed. However, we were seated quickly. The servers were extremely hospitable and checked on us multiple times! The interior was beautiful. Gold decorations and intricate lighting decor hung across the ceiling. The walls and ceiling were adorned with beautiful patterns. The place looked extremely upscale!

[Lao Fried Rice] The fried rice had a nice mix of diced veggies and chicken. I loved the poignant taste of basil leaves. It came with a fried egg which had a liquid yolk, and three fried chicken wings. The portion size was huge and lasted me two meals!
author: Annie Z.

description:
I've been here twice and liked it both times
Highlight is the ambience and food. It's a really mice place with some interesting pieces of art on the walls and ceiling. Food presentation was pretty good along with the service. 

Food quality was good and the quantity was pretty big for a single person.
author: Arjan N.

description:
A lovely, elegant atmosphere is complemented by attentive service--and mediocre food. Lao Table is a relatively new restaurant in SoMa, and the lunch service definitely caters to the business crowd. While the food wasn't bad, it wasn't at all worth the exorbitant prices, and I wouldn't be in a rush to return.

The crispy sticky rice salad was definitely the best dish I tried--the rice had an amazing crispy texture and was accompanied by a slightly sour fermented pork sausage. It was also served with plenty of veggies and herbs on the side, which really balanced out the dish! The om chicken curry was served in a clear curry broth and had a ton of herbal flavor, delicious veggies, and a spicy kick. However, the white meat chicken in the curry was quite boring, and the dish was missing finesse and a balance of flavors. The "pad mee" prawn stir-fried noodles came in a generous portion and was served with bean sprouts, peanuts, and ground chilies on the side. However, the noodles were a little on the sweet side (similar flavors to an Americanized Pad Thai) and quite boring overall. Not at all worth the almost $20 price tag.

While the space here is nicely decorated and the service good, the food could use some improvement, especially given the high price points. While some of their other dishes looked interesting, there are plenty of other Southeast Asian places in the Bay Area with more authentic flavors and better value than Lao Table.
author: David K.

description:
Beautiful presentation, thematically Laotian food with pretty slow service. 

I have to say that thank god im half Laotian because I knew exactly what to order. If I wasn't, I'd be scared because the server had no insight to offer about the menu, no specials, no "I realize Laotian food is extremely rare and most people aren't familiar with it, let me guide you through the menu and make some recommendations" 

It was at least 14 minutes before we were greeted/had our order taken and there were other tables right there with us who waited less or even longer. We couldn't tell who was a busser or server. Just really disorganized and quite possibly a lack of team communication on their end. 

We ordered everything I know, and I know about how it should taste. I would say it's pretty authentic. 

Nam khao- coconut rice ball fried, then broken into fried rice mixture with scallions, cured pork sausage and pork skin. Extra spicy and delicious! 

Bamboo salad- 9$ not as finely shaved as my grandma did hers, but the flavor was spot on and of course spicy as all hell. 

Papaya salad- 20$ yummy, fermented goodness, I was just thrown off by all the actual crab shells they left in the papaya because I kept almost cutting myself with those sharp shells. 

Khaw khai- 21$ chow fun (wide flat rice noodles) sautéed with egg and chicken, similar to pad Thai. Pretty good. 

Our server didn't want to offer us dessert so we had to just ask for it when she presented the bill. 

Our bill ended up being 135$ after everything, which is steep for 3rd world country food. So something to think about when deciding to dine here. I'd introduce friends to a cheaper more authentic spot ( I have yet to find one) before committing to this restaurant. 

I realize that this was the financial district so rent is insane which is why everything was so expensive, but the service was like going to mom and pop restaurant and grandpa (who has never served) is serving you. Clearly, this is run by a corporate/restaurant group so I'm just surprised to see such spotty service. There was no clear manager in sight just a bunch of unaware kids. 

Price does not reflect the service, the actual ingredients are not that expensive, just labor intensive. You're paying for the location. 

Food -4/5
Service-2/5 
Ambiance-3/5

 Overall 3.5, I don't need to come back.
author: Megan K.

description:
Right in the heart of financial district so expect to pay premium for Lao foods.  This is not authentic Lao food per se but it's good enough. 

Customer service is great! Place is clean and nicely decorated.

Food is quite pricey for the obvious reason.

We ordered the following dishes:

Crispy sticky rice salad.  It's a nice dish that is served with Roman salad.  Although I prefer to have this dish at another restaurant in Oakland.

Scallops:  a plate of 5 overly season scallops. The scallops was cooked just right however I find this dish a bit over seasoned. Definitely have to eat it with rice.

Sea bass: cooked with curry banana leaves. This dished was over cooked and very dry. If you know anything about sea bass it's hard to over cook this fish yet dry. Not recommended.

Pad Thai shrimps: dish was good. 

Steaks: perfectly cooked and love the seasoning. Highly recommend this dish.

Pork belly: we opted for the sticky rice as our side dish. The combo was Fantastic! Dish is very flavorful. Must try!

Papaya salads: this dish was alright. I prefer the Thai style.

Calamari: not your typical American calamari. It's a whole squid served fillet with a dipping sauce. Highly recommended.

They serve fresh young coconut and they have full bar.
author: Hollie H.

description:
I walk by this place almost everyday. I watched it get built & I never walked in until I saw a sign that says "HAPPY HOUR: $1 oysters" Done. Sold! I'm coming in! They offer happy hour Monday-Friday 5-7, with a small select menu.

I came walked in & was blown away by the decor! Amazingly gorgeous. The hostess table is covered in flowers! And from what I see from outside it's always changing flowers. I was greeted right away, extremely friendly staff! If you're ordering happy hour you can only sit at the bar area. Everything I ordered was off the happy hour menu, small little snacks.

-Tom yum fries: 4/5
Just amazing those Tom yum ramen noodle packs. Get the powder out & instead of pouring them on your ramen, pour them over fries. Genius!!!! It was delicious. I need to start doing that at home. 

-Garlic chicken wings: 4/5
It was delicious. Comes with six wings stacked on each other.... stylish! Perfect combination of savory & sweet. 

-Lao sausage: 2/5
Probably my least favorite. There's a strong flavor of lemon grass and I'm not a fan. Huge chunks of ginger inside. Overall, not a fan.

-Vegetarian rolls: 3/5
These were just okay to me. Nothing extra special. Just steam veggies wrapped into an egg roll, served with a sweet and sour sauce which I wasn't too fond of as well. 

-$1 oysters: 5/5
THE ONLY REASON I CAME! They impressed me. Oysters were huge!!!! Served in buckets with a side of their special house sauce.... delicious! I wish I had that every time I got raw oysters! Squeeze some lemon, slap on their house sauce & pop them oysters in your mouth.... PERFECTION! Sad side you can only order 6 at a time. Just make sure you don't come in after happy hour! 

Overall I enjoyed my experience. The staff was nice, service was fast! It can be a bit cramped in the bar area because the tables are a tad close. Had to maneuver my way out.
author: Kathy T.

description:
RIGID THAI!  First of all,i really fascinated with their decoration. The combination between Thai Laotian and modern style which so fantastic and creative! 

Their food are authentic , serve fresh on Thai style dish 
Servers also nice and friendly 

I love their bbq chicken. It was so tender and juicy and it really goes with special dip and sticky rice. Dont miss ur chance to try  this amazing Thai bbq chicken  

You gotta eat here even the price quite high but it worth for rigid Thai
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
Ambiance: Thumb's up! Great for group dinner. Sleek and modern. 

Costumer service: Awesome! Attentative and pleasant. Reasonable time for food. 

Food quality: "Ok". Nothing to brag about but not bad either. Over-priced in my opinion, for what you get. Sticky rice with meal was very dry. Fried fish was beautifully presented, but dry to taste. The chicken was very tasty and delicious. We had the mango/sticky rice for dessert but the mango was not ripe and sour instead of sweet. 

I would come back, but probably wouldn't be my fist choice.
author: Mel T.

description:
An ok experience, but wasn't quite good enough to want to try it again (on my own dime at least hah).  

We selected a lot of vegetarian dishes, and the prices for food alone (without the drinks) still came out to over $30 per person (including tax and tip).  The food was also essentially Thai, and so I guess I'm used to that genre of food being more reasonably priced. 

Dishes we tried: 
Tum Marg Hoong Papaya Salad -- only came with three lettuce wraps even though we had five people. 
Pad Mee prawns -- essentially like pad thai except a different kind of noodle.  
Spicy Eggplant -- Good flavor, though the tofu was a bit dry. 
Mok Seabass -- the fish inside the wrap was quite small, and the exterior flavoring was so spicy, that you could barely taste the fish. 
Spicy Steak Lao -- not that it wasn't good, but didn't see exactly what part of this dish was particularly Laoatian...

The service was also a bit rushed.  The dessert menu was showed to us before we even finished the main courses.  

Wasn't too busy at all on a Saturday night, though we made reservations anyways.
author: Alison L.

description:
Amazing!!!  I stopped by the place with a group of friends on Friday night. The place was pack but it took less than 5 mins to get the table. I had crying tiger beef--no word to describe how delish it was!!!  My friends order garden fish ---served with few small sides. The portion is HUGE!! We also had the hot pot which I forgot the name, Love it!! 
Excellent food, great service. 

I actually come back to order crying tiger steak for take out now lol!!!
author: Marina K.

description:
It was Jamie W. who recommended we try this Laotian offshoot of Osha Thai, which surprised me since I'm usually the one yanking his chain to go somewhere new. The place looks a lot like the Osha Thai it was before with its dark clubby lighting and crowded-together tables. That's because co-owners Lalita Souksamlane and Wassana Korkhieola smartly stick with a successful marketing formula since Osha Thai is the Thai restaurant chain its competitors try to mimic often with lackluster results. Souksamlane takes charge here as she was raised in a Thai town that bordered Laos, and the cuisine crosses that border with relative ease.

Where the restaurant went south was the often ridiculously slow service that dragged out our meal there unnecessarily. We were seated between two incessantly verbal parties of four, so Jamie and I were being constantly tortured by their vacuous comments. In the midst of this stereophonic symphony of inanity, we managed to order the $22.95 Khao Nar Ped which provided slices of honey-roasted duck, a hard-boiled egg, and cucumber with a honey soy sauce, all over jasmine rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2qeRu18). A bit pricey for a relatively simple dish, but duck is duck so who's complaining?

Our next dish was the $16.95 "Khaw Kai" Noodles, which was a hearty bowl of thick rice noodles mixed with chicken pieces, chopped peanuts, scallions, bean sprouts, and caramel soy sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2qJIh4o). It was good journeyman eats that makes up in flavor what it lacks in creativity. It was probably about five minutes between the first two dishes, but the third dish came over half an hour later. The seemingly straightforward $14 Mixed Vegetables were mixed in a wok with deep-fried tofu and mushroom in an oyster sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2q5yQxC), but its journey from the kitchen to our table was an interminable one.

It was like watching Shelley Winters in "The Poseidon Adventure" as you keep waiting for her to die because somehow you know the fat lady can't survive all that breathless swimming to save Gene Hackman from certain death. We were also waiting for the fat lady to die by the time the vegetables arrived along with a bowl of rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2qbYc92). You would think we'd be ready to leave, but I really wanted us to share the $18 Mark Som & Mark Wan, an elaborate bowl of exotic Southeast Asian fruit on ice topped by macarons, a fruity sorbet and gelatin (photo: http://bit.ly/2rbMqzH). I saw it go by to another table, and I felt we deserved one, a lovely end note to a somewhat erratic evening.

FOOD - 4 stars...mostly more than decent Laotian dishes with the topper being that fruit bowl
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...I loathe the table set-up which pushes tables together as if we were unwilling participants in a communal meal
SERVICE - 2 stars...nice enough when the servers came, but their visits to our table were few and far between
TOTAL - 3 stars...snail's-pace service and crowded tables torpedoed a promising evening
author: Ed U.

description:
Laotian or Thai, who cares?!

A few friends and I got together here for lunch. I'd that there was a connection between Lao Table and Osha but that did not make any sense since Osha serves Thai food and Lao advertises as a Laotian option. Then I did what any information junkie would do and googled it. Here is the scoop. Executive Chef and owner Lalita Souksamlane who grew up on the border of Thailand and Laos decided to introduce the food that she grew up eating in this venue.

Granted that in my first and only visit I did not try more than an appetizer a main dish, still I was very pleased with the pleasant flavors that I got to taste. So while I am not well educated on the distinctions between the two country's cuisines and the borderland cuisine's specifics, "frankly my dear, I don't give a damn" because it all tastes so good!

The servers are very good at what they do and the space is beautiful. So what do you have to lose? Give it a try!
author: Afshin A.

description:
Sparkling wine - Pretty good
Apetizer- Koi tuna- good
Laotian fried rice with egg and fried chicken - Great
Noodle and Crab curry- Thought it was way overpriced for the amount of noodle and crab. Have as little veggies as possible in this as customer wants crabs and not veggies !
Ambience- Great!
author: Amol S.

description:
Great southeast Asian spot at financial district~ super cute plates and bowls and cups. Good cocktail and entrees~ great for a Friday happy hour with coworkers after work~~~ great quality Laotian/Thai food 
The mango ice dessert is the bomb! Definitely order that~
author: Shirley Z.

description: I went here with my coworkers for lunch & had a great time. Very friendly & attentive staff & a fancier set up than most typical Thai food restaurants. I ordered the Basil chicken & it was absolutely delicious, highly recommend. I also ordered a Thai ice tea which was a bit sweeter than I usually like but overall good experience.
author: LeVar H.

description:
We came here for a Thursday lunch. The restaurant interior was clean and spacious, and the service was average in terms of friendliness and speed.

I ordered a Basil Chicken Rice Bowl for $16.95 (!!!), which consisted of wok-fried chicken, chili garlic, holy (?!) basil, and jasmine rice with a fried egg on top. The bowl tasted really good, and although the chicken was a bit too spicy for me, it was flavorful and tasty. The quantity was good for lunch, but both the quality and quantity combined was not worth the expensive price.

We asked them if we could split the bill 6 ways for our group, and they told us at first that they couldn't, then changed their minds and agreed to do it. I appreciated this; however, it took them a good 15 minutes to bring the 6 bills to us. They also charged us automatic gratuity for our group of 7, which I did not appreciate and believe has never earned a restaurant a higher rating.

NOTE: At least I learned that holy basil is a real thing while writing this review.
author: George L.

description:
I ordered: 

* Moo Nam Pla (pork belly) - This is way better than I was expecting because usually pork belly is too fatty for me, but the crispiness of the pork belly made it seem less fatty.
* Pad Moo Pa - This is really good too, but I wished they gave more rice for the amount of meat they give. For those of you who can't take spicy foods, you can ask to get it mild.
author: Jamie N.

description:
Been to this place for a couple times. Their garlic chicken wings is a must try, so flavorful! Some curry dishes we ordered were also pretty good, but the soup for duck pho was not hot enough.

For lunch, don't forgot to come before noon, otherwise it'll be very crowded.
author: Lu D.

description: Great place, great food, took our 18 and 7 year old for dinner and both cleared their plates. Cocktails were okay, wait staff was fabulous. We would definitely come back and recommend to friends.
author: Meloney Q.

description:
Came here twice for lunch and foods are pretty good. A bit pricey for Thai foods since they try to be the upscale Thai restaurant with nice decors (even foods are nicely presented). Portions are generous. Love their eggplant dish, pineapple fried rice, and pad pha beef. 

Recommend if you want a nice place for Thai.
author: Lena H.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Thursday night and the restaurant was quite busy. However, I was able to get a table even without reservations. The interior decor was impressive, much so that it seems like a great place to bring a date. The guests sitting at the next table seemed like they were on one. The wait staff was super friendly too.

I decided to start with the Pad Mee Prawns. I particularly liked the presentation, with garnishes on the side and a flower with the bean sprouts. The dish was savory and flavorful, reminiscent of pad thai. The second dish that I ordered was the Kha Moo German, which is a crispy skin pork knuckle. I didn't like this dish as much as I thought that the amount of protein that you get was limited. It was mostly bone and fat. The crispiness on the skin was tasty, though. For the price, it was not worth it. Regardless, I wouldn't mind coming back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Suor K.

description: Very nice setting in the middle of SF downtown, with excellent service. Shrimp curry was excellent! Lao-style duck on rice was pretty good, but duck meat was a bit hard.
author: Y C.

description:
Decent Laos restaurant located in the SoMa district in SF. Came with a group of friends right when the restaurant opened for dinner, so we didn't need to wait in line and were seated without reservation.

We ordered a few entrees to share:
- Khao Nar Ped, a couple of pieces of duck over rice. The duck was very flavorful but it was a very small portion for the price.
- Pork belly, really well cooked, juicy, and tender, but also very small portion.
- Khaw Khai noodles: basically just flat noodles with some chicken, was rather greasy.
- Mok seabass, this was very spicy (not my preference).
- German pork knuckle, this was the highlight. The knuckle had a lot of meat and was incredibly juicy. The meat was so tender it just fell apart off the bone. The meat soaked a lot of the sauces very well.

Overall, the flavors were good but the portions were very small for the price.
author: Alvin W.

description:
We went for dinner and to try the oysters. They don't even shuck the oysters for you! They're still stick to the muscle and they don't include a knife to cut it with. When we asked for a knife we were brought a dull butter knife. To make it worse the third oyster I tried I nearly puked. It tasted NASTY I couldn't eat anymore after that. I also had grilled calamari. This was very tough and flavorless. It smelt like wet dog and didn't taste much better. Stay far away from this place.

We asked them if they could shuck the oysters for us and they said they didn't do that there. We asked for a tool and they brought out a dull butter knife.
author: Maisie R.

description:
I was in town for a conference and our group of 7 decided to eat here. They take reservations which was great so we booked a time, walked on over and arrived just in time. 

The place had great service and good drinks. We ordered the spring rolls, the crispy rolls, the pineapple fried rice, the crab curry, the Khaw Kai noodles. Everything overall was good. We were stuffed when we left and had a ton of food leftover so they definitely don't skimp on the portions.
author: Courtney D.

description:
Came here on a Monday night for Happy Hour on Monday Night at 6:30 pm. Not too much of a wait, we sat on the side of the restaurant when they were serving happy hour.

The menu was pricey so we opted to just order a couple of happy hour snacks to split. My friend and I each got an order of the garlic wings ($8) and got a vegetarian egg rolls to split ($7).

The wings were pretty good (you get about 6) and they're kind of sweet but crispy and hot when they come out! Your hands will be sticky but it's worth it :). A solid 4/5 

The vegetarian egg rolls were delicious! So hot and crispy and the sauce was the perfect sweetness to offset the savoriness of the roll. Definitely recommend and 6 pieces for $7 is great! 

Would love to give the dinner menu a shot but it's just so pricey (everything upward of $16) for an entree except the salads and appetizers. 

Service was pretty good and the lady let us even grab another of the wine (Cabernet) at the happy hour price even though by halfway through our meal it was past happy hour price! 

Would recommend for a happy hour but not sure if I could justify the prices for dinner!
author: Kristie M.

description:
Modern Lao restaurant. Great ambience and sexy vibe.

Food stays close to being authentic without losing itself in its trendiness. The veggies are always fresh and there is no skimping on the additions/herbs. 

Cons: Prices are higher than average and portions are small.

Pros: Quality, service
author: Star K.

description: Beautiful atmosphere, great service despite the fact that I was tricked into ordering an $80 steak (although it was delicious), beautiful plating, and most importantly delicious food! I highly recommend the crispy rice salad. Although portions are small, everything was packed with flavor. The huge Thai ice tea was also a fun touch, and the grass jelly made it unique.
author: Charissa S.

description:
being lao myself i wouldnt normally want to pay alot for food i can make at home. but seeing how many high views it has and friends who ate here--i figure we gotta try it! came @1:00 today (friday) it was packed! we got very lucky and snagged the last table. what we ordered:

mok seabass- $25.95 taste very authentic but kind of overpriced.

payapa salad platter- $21.95 it was decent i ask for laotian style but ill pass next time.

tom zaab lao- $19.95- soup for the soul with fresh herbs. spareribs were sooo tender! 

larb duck- $22.95 aw man definetly get it! and i never make larb with duck but its so flavorful. i need to. 

moo nam pla- $11.95 it was cheapest dish we got but honestly the BEST dish we got. 


the sticky rice was alot for the amount you get. $4.5 per order and just enough for one person. drinks itself pricey too. herbal tea was $7.
author: Lisa V.

description:
EVERYTHING we tried was delicious! And the servers were kind and attentive. We called ahead of time to reserve for New Year's Eve dinner, they accommodated our reservation and special requests for seating.

Dishes ordered: Zeen Ping, Tom-Zaab Beef (I remember we were all pleasantly surprised how tender the meat was in addition to the refreshing flavor), Suae Hong Hai (Crying Tiger Steak - juicy and delicious as it should be!), Mok Seabass, Kurobuta Pork Belly. 

Great ambiance for a special occasion dinner, or any night you want to make a little more special. On New Year's Eve they had special performances. I look forward to coming back when I can.
author: Mingming C.

description: The food was SO good! Khaw Kai is my personal favorite. We didn't have to wait long and my group of 6 loved every single dish that they were served.
author: Stephen P.

description:
Lao Table has great food and a nice ambiance. It's a rather unassuming restaurant from outside, but it delivered a punch. The only nitpick on the interior is that the tables are almost on top of one another, so prepare to get cozy.

We had dinner and drinks here which consisted of the famous gigantic pineapple cocktail, Pineapple Millionaire, which was absolutely delicious, Smile Buffalo (another drink), Red Curry Chicken, and Basil Chicken.

Service was quick, and the entrees were tasty. Would definitely come back here.
author: Nic Z.

description: We came here tonight. I was impressed about the ambiance and food. Very good food. Love the heart of banana salad. Yum yum!  The services was also excellent. They always ask us how are we doing.
author: Anna T.

description: Wow. The interior decoration at Lao Table top notch. I stopped in after work for happy hour and had the papaya salad and Thai sausage. What a great snack. Great atmosphere and the bartender was a riot. I'll have the oyster special next time. It looked really good.
author: Mimi K.

description: I visited Lao Table on Friday night. It was later so they were a little less busy. I was greeted promptly and seated quickly. The waitstaff was helpful and answered all the questions that I had. I had the Larb Duck and crispy salad and everything was delicious. There is a reason this place is so busy. When I'm back in town again I'll definitely return!
author: Tanya B.

description:
First time I've been back since it changed from Osha Thai to Lao Table, and happy to say I still love this place just as much!

Seven of us came here for a work dinner and not only were the staff quick to seat us and take our orders, but the food came out very quickly. 

We all shared the chicken Satay skewers and the veggie spring rolls and they were really delicious. For mains people mostly got the curries - I got the prawn curry, which came with a side of steamed rice and was presented so nicely it felt like it would have been rude NOT to take a picture to share...

The flavours were mouth watering, and the spice level was a little kick without setting me on fire. I'm not normally one for sweet things in my savory food (pineapple on pizza is a huge no for me), but the pineapple and whole lychees in the curry actually made it! 

The portion sizes are generous, the ambience is fancy but not awkwardly so, and now they have redone the place there is a LOT more seating.

Sure, a little more expensive than it used to be but a lovely place to go out for a treat or on a date night. I know I'll definitely be back
author: Jemma B.

description:
Food:
+ Creative and palatably presented 
+ Hearty portion though the food begins to taste monotonous so I'd recommend going family style. 
- $$

Service:
+ Attentive service

Ambiance: 
+ Nice interior design and decor with high ceiling and well spaced tables.
author: Linda K.

description: Came here for a team lunch on a Friday-- the food is great and our server was one of the friendliest I've ever had. They have fresh coconuts! Ambiance is slightly more on the fancy side.
author: Maggie S.

description:
Tried Lao with a friend. We did not have a reservation and on a Friday. We were seated fairly quickly and had good very prompt. Prices are a bit high (welcome to San Francisco) but boy were the portions large and food wonderful. I ordered a noodle dish with no peanuts. Friend had another noodle dish. Couple next to us enjoyed the fruit platter- although i did not order it, it looked AMAZING.

We wanted. Quick bite and everything form ordering eating and paying took about 45 minutes. Keep up the good work!
author: Amanda M.

description:
Very good asian cuisine!
Very accurate ingredients and tastes.
Fabulous service.
Great experience!
Warmly recommended
author: Or P.

description:
This restaurant was suggested to me via Facebook, and I'm so happy I checked it out further. 

My husband and I are recent vegetarians, and Lao Table's menu had plenty of meat and non-meat selections to choose from. 

We had the vegetarian Lao and Pineapple fried rice. They were both phenomenal. To start we also had their Vegetarian Crispy Rolls. Also quite delicious. 

Their decor was super fun, and the noise level was moderate. Overall, great service and even better food. I'd highly recommend to anyone who asks for a good spot to eat when visiting San Fransisco.
author: Ashleigh F.

description: I came here with my family for the first time. The food was good, pretty authentic, and great presentation. We ordered garden fish, nam, moo pla, and fried rice. The price is a little bit pricey but it's still reasonable. The only thing that BAD was the SERVICE. It was sucks! We got charged 20% tips plus employee mandates but we don't really got any service. Our server was gone or missing somewhere because we have to ask other server for extra utensils, re-ordered more food, and check. I used to wait table too, It's not right to charge gratuity and then ignored your customers.
author: Helen S.

description:
OHHHHH MY F*%!'n Gosh!!!! We cruisin' thru Cali and landed on Lao Table thru Yelp and we're soooooo glad we did! We came on a Tuesday nite (Thank God) cuz we had 2 young kids with us and we got in, ate, and UMMMMMM!!!!! Lemme go head and point out the HIGHLIGHT of our meals. 
1. Tiger Cry Steak- OH MY LANTA!!!!! This was the BEST Tiger Cry Steak I've ever had in my whole entire life!! It just MELTED in our mouths and the jeow SET IT OFF!!!! Linh cut sum for her daughter and she didn't wanna eat it so u darn skippy we took that back! Shooooot #DEVOURED!
2. Foie Gras- THIS IS A MUST!!!! This duck liver patè strait melted in our mouths! U HAVE TO eat it with the lil coconut crispy thingy and lettuce that it came with! It's like BUTTA BABEE!!! 
3. Iono bout Linh's drink but my Lao Soda was THE BOMB!! It was made of kifir vodka and watermelon juice. Got me tipsy as hell!
4. Garlic wings was good but we didn't bother too too much with it cuz we had wings at a Chinese restaurant earlier. But the lil crispy stuff was bomb! Reminded me of them Salt n pepper crispy thingys. 
5. The crispy egg roll wrap. Ummmmmmm!! So crunchy and refreshing! Oh, and it's vegetarian. Aye! 
6. Fried pork belly. The kids ate that. It was aiiite. The jeow wasn't spicy or anything but hey if the kids liked it we loved it cuz.. Whatever makes them eat! U know?!??

Over all, our experience was GREAT! Service was EXCELLENT!!! Looking back on Yelp we're like Oh damn! We didn't order this n that... But don't worry.. We'll def be back here!!! #TopNotch #MeltInYoMow #1inSF #HIGHLYrecommended  #HiSoForReal #TravelodgeToEatGood :/ :) :D :p
author: Asia T.

description:
It's so cute inside and I think that's the best part. 

Right out of the gate, service wasn't what it should have been. We had a small wait with a reservation and the hostess minorly scolded one person in our party about their umbrella and the bagging thing they have. 

Once we're sat, we continue to sit for between 5-10 minutes without menus and no server comes over or greets us. I get up to ask for menus from the hostess who was maybe too worried about the umbrella being wrapped up than about serving her main function of getting a reservation sat on time, giving them menus, or assigning them a server. 

When our server did eventually come to the table, we were surprisingly met with a lot of. 'Nos'. 
+ Can I get an iced tea? No. 
+ Can I get the basil leaves dish with shrimp instead of chicken? No. 

Ok you don't have iced tea- can you tell us what beverages you do have because we didn't get a beverage menu and/or you don't list your non-alcoholic drinks on your menu. 

You have shrimp, you have shrimp dishes- why can't you use chicken instead of shrimp? Server's answer: 'Fine 5 more dollars'. 
Me: It sounds like you just made that price up, but fine. It's a work lunch anyway.

That $5 made it a now $22 lunch dish that was the least flavorful of its kind I've ever had. It was dry and lacked the spice I was expecting. I wanted to ask the server if I could get extra of the gravy that was so minimally used in the dish but of course he never came back. Also, the smallest portion of this dish I've been served anywhere for the highest price.

For a nice atmosphere work lunch in SoMa with very average food an sub-par service, I guess it'll do, but I'm not aching to go back to a place with just ok food, that doesn't accommodate its customers (but will scold them), and service that is borderline absent.
author: Candice G.

description: I tasted my first Laos dish here and it was amazing, will definitely coming back when we're in the area.
author: Kendra M.

description:
The place has a modern decor and clean bathrooms which is a plus, but it is on the pricier side of things even for SF.  For a group of 6 we paid around $50 each w/tax & tip. They let you make reservations so if you're coming with a large group I would recommend it since it does get packed. 

WHAT WE GOT: We basically did everything family style.

- Lao Soda Cocktail ($13) - #watermelon. If you want something refreshing but with a twist I would get this. It tastes like juice and they give you a chunk of fresh watermelon with your drink.

- Vegetarian Crispy Rolls ($8.95) - 6 half pieces - Great option if you want to share and for your vegetarian/vegan friends.

- Duck wings ($16.95) - 4 pieces - Pricey for what you get, but they were tasty. Not fatty as what you think you'd get with duck. 

- Pineapple Fried Rice ($17.95) - Meh. Nothing too special.

- Pho Duck ($22.95) - OK. Nothing too special either. You get a few pieces that you can share but it tasted a bit overcooked

- Totally Prawns ($22.95) - Yum. Love me some curry with a coconut base. It's more veggie than prawns and not as rich of a broth as I'd like but it's still tasty.

- Kurobota Pork Belly ($25.95) - YUM. This just melts in your mouth. Not the largest portion but it's a great one to try and share if you want to splurge on a dish

SERVICE: 

Pretty solid in my book. We came 15 mins earlier than our reservation and they sat our group down anyways. We were also waiting for people to come before ordering but they never made us feel rushed. During out dinner they came around often to refill our waters without us even asking and helped clean up empty dishes early.
author: Keizzel C.

description: It is an awesome restaurant! If you ever go to it, don't forget to order GARLIC PEPPER PORK or BASIL CHICKEN. They are both so good and in big portion. We went there for 2 times and we tried $1 oyster deal there, it was really small and we could only order 5 each time.  We also tried pad pha beef which is apparently not good and the portion is not enough.
author: Shuang W.

description:
I was very sad when I saw Osha closing, but then they opened Lao Table and boy, now I have a new favorite Thai place downtown. Their Thai Iced Coffee is one of the best I've ever tried. It's so good, and not just that, but the presentation is pretty amazing.

The local is beautiful, and service is awesome. Not great for big groups, but definitely one of my to-go places from now on!
author: Antonio H.

description:
I came here with my parents, looking for a new restaurant to try. We were slightly nervous when we saw that the place was only half-full. It was a Friday night and just about everywhere else was PACKED. Still, the yelp reviews were good and we had a reservation (super easy to make through yelp- we made ours 10 min before walking there), so in we went.

The first thing I noticed was the atmosphere- it was classy without being stuffy, and had mood-setting lighting without getting too dark.

The staff were super attentive, walking around to refill water often, and ask if we needed anything. 

But the food. The food was the real star. First of all, everything was plated BEAUTIFULLY! Almost every dish had an orchid adorning its plate. The industrial engineer in me started crunching numbers to estimate how many orchids they must go through in a week. Even the drinks were gorgeous! I didn't order any of these for myself, but looking around at the other tables, i know i'll have to come back and try something!

We ordered the fresh spring rolls, tamarind beef, kha kai noodles, and mixed vegetables. 

The spring rolls were SO FRESH. They put mint in them and it was the most amazing thing to start our meal. They wrap the vegetables with three layers of noodle, which I thought was going to be too thick, but it ended up being really delicious :) 

The tamarind beef was served with eggplant and the sauce was SO GOOD! I beef was a little tough, but I'm also not a huge beef fan in general.

The mixed vegetables was what I was least excited for, but they surprised me! It was served with tofu and ended up being the perfect balance to the spicy dishes we ordered.

My favorite was definitely the kha kai noodles. The noodles were deceptively spicy, and served with a side dish of more chili sauce. A+ in my books :)

HIGHLY RECOMMEND COMING HERE!!! I know I'll be making a return visit ;)
author: Waverly R.

description:
I got the panang beef curry for lunch. It was on today's lunch special and coated around $14. I thought it was super good and wished I had more. The waitress said the spice level is from 1-5 and I got a 4 but I barely tasted any spice at all, so if you like spice, keep that in mind.

We also got a Tom yum soup and that was also really good. It was on the sweeter side with some coconut milk mixed in.  It also had a shit ton of mushroom so if you don't like mushroom that could be a problem. 

I think the food was a bit on the pricey side for a casual lunch so it would be a great place to go for a company lunch if you don't have to pay for it lolz
author: Stephanie K.

description: Ordered food to be delivered via Yelp. Everything was tasty and the food was delivered on time.
author: Elmira R.

description:
Beautiful and intimate interior, great service, fancy food presentation, but only better-than-decent food with high pricing. 

I came here for a small dinner/snack with my sister. It was basically empty by 9:00pm so we got seated immediately we ordered two things to share. 

-Spring rolls: 8 bites (rolled and cut like sushi), with a thicker, more opaque rice wrap. While everything held together well, there was barely any taste of the pork sausage or anything else inside. I had to use the peanut dip (which was too syrupy sweet) to add some flavor. Not at all worth the $11 in my opinion 

-Kaw Khai noodles: Delicious but not mind-blowing. The two things they did right was 1. boingy noodles 2. ratios of sweetness, spiciness, and saltiness. Everything else seemed pretty standard--the chicken was a little dry. Flavors were good but portion-size was weird: a bit small for two people to share but too much for one person to eat alone. 

I don't think I'd come back here to try the other foods since I've had same quality and cheaper noodles elsewhere. The priciness seems unnecessary. I rather go to a cheaper place and get more food. 

This place had the ambience of a fancy top-notch restaurant but the food quality doesn't match-up.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Beef jerky here is tasty, first time to have fresh made beef jerky.

Lao Sausage is just so-so. The prawn with pineapple and lychee is so good, not big portion tho, guess that's why people in the city are so fit!

The atmosphere here is cozy, clean, very comfortable with affordable price, really a gem.

The restroom is spacious and clean and there is a wall with art, I like it.

Not too busy on Friday night either.

The service is very good; the plates are pretty.
author: Stephanie W.

description: This place deserves 5 stars. Great customer service, good food, good drinks, and if you want a nice outing with your significant other, family, or friend this is the place to be!! Get the crispy sticky rice, Lao sausage for appetizer, spicy eggplant with beef(ain't spicy), and the fried pork with the sausage! All my southeast Asian homie this is a place to be and your non Asian friends! Bless your non-Asian friends with a good place to eat!!!
author: Ramonny C.

description:
Quite frankly, this spot seems way overpriced to me (then again, so does all of San Francisco). The service is good, ambiance interesting, but the food, which should be the star of the show, is honestly just okay. I tried the Laotian Fried Rice (veggie) and I get very similar food stuffs at my local Chinese take out joint for a lot cheaper. It was fresh and the veggies tasted great, but I didn't find it to blow my mind, which at $30 some odd $$ it should.

I get why this spot is what it is but it isn't worth it to me. Save some money and go somewhere else.
author: Aruna A.

description: The food is pretty good, the prices are kinda high. Would happily eat here if it was a company event
author: Michelle R.

description:
The calameri is really good but the rest of those are a bit pricy. 
The environment is not bad, and service is good.
Worth a try.
author: Rui X.

description: Went there for Valentines,love the atmosphere and unexpected traditional Thai music+dancers.  Staff were so attentive.  My husband was so excited to go there for tomahawk but unavailable.  He was quite disappointed and I enjoyed everything.
author: Lan C.

description: Maybe it's because I'm vegetarian, but this place seemed a bit pricey for what it offered -- the dish I got was decent. Nothing super special, and it seemed more like veggies stir fried in some sauce and not really worth the price point.
author: Annie T.

description:
Lunch for 2.

- Ambiance (3/5)
Beautiful interior though very cramped and extremely loud. Never like shouting across the table to be heard. 

- Service (2/5)
Friendly but exceptionally slow. The food comes out pretty quickly but water slow to be filled, and check took forever. 

- Grilled Calamari, $14.95 (5/5)
Great presentation and cookery. Really delicious sauce. 

- Kurobuta Pork Belly, $25.95 (5/5)
Haven't had pork belly like this in some time. And the accompaniments- mustard greens and water spinach worked so well. 

- Value (4/5)
Considering the quality and the portions this is pretty good value. 

- Final Word
This really was a 5 star food experience though the ambiance and service give me pause.
author: Jeff J.

description: To start, I would like to say that I am a huge fan of the interior of this place - the aesthetics are very pleasing. In terms of the food, overall I had a very solid meal. I had the fried rice and calamari. The fried rice didn't stand out to me but was by no means bad. The calamari here was interesting. I didn't expect to be given the entire piece of squid but the calamari was very flavorful and the sauce complimented the squid nicely. Will definitely check out this place again if I am in the area
author: Kevin T.

description:
We came here because of the good reviews but were a bit skeptical once we walked in. It's true, the decor was nicer than most "stereotypically authentic" restaurants and the prices high but the food was good too.

We had: 
-Vegetable spring rolls: more delicate and less oily than most spring rolls
-Shrimp tom kha soup: one of the better tom kha soups I've had...very tasty!
-Shrimp curry: I liked the addition of the peaches and the coconut rice was delicious!

It's a little pricey but all in all, I'm happy we came here and that there's a nice, tasty Asian restaurant in this area!

3.5 stars
author: Ninette C.

description: This place is lovely for small groups of friends or dates. Service is amazing. Food has good portion with great taste.
author: Yue Y.

description:
My favorite spot for a group lunch during the week. They serve delicious, inventive, and widely varied dishes that are beautifully presented and cooked with fantastic flavors. Book a table on Yelp because they can get packed.

I'm a big fan of the Lao fried rice and khaw kai noodles; the portions are large enough that you'll have something to take away (or you're going to need a nap afterward). If you're into the chicken-and-rice trend that's hit SF lately, order the khao mun gai and don't skimp on the sauce. Atkins dieters will find a handful of protein-and-vegetable dishes at the pricier end of the menu. I've heard good things about the pho but I've never ordered it, since there are plenty of other places to get that in the City. 

The one lunch challenge at Lao Table is speed of service. It's not uncommon for some dishes to come out several minutes before others, so practice your politely frustrated "please get started without me" speech. When they're slammed it can also be hard to get someone to bring the check, so if you've got to head back for an after-lunch meeting, ask to pay as soon as the food arrives.
author: Alex L.

description: Do not make reservations here! I made reservations for a large group 1 month in advance and every time I followed up they did not have me down. They could careless and had the worst customer experience. Honestly - the WORST experience.
author: Bridgett C.

description: Restaurant has great vibe, friendly staff, and delicious dishes. We had the Lao Sausage, Suae Hong Thai, and Khao Poon (Crab Curry Noodles). The flavors are rich and refreshing. Our waiter gave great recommendations!
author: Mavette S.

description: Price higher than normal Thai restaurant but the food are delicious. We order a Pineapple fried rice, mixed veggie, red curry and tom Yung hotpot( this is the big one, better for 4 ppl or more). Remember it close at 3 pm for lunch hour!
author: Manwai U.

description: I've been here couple times, should say I'm a fan for sure. I love how they redesign the interior decoration and make it more elegant. The food is amazing, especially the dishware, they are a set for every single dish, which makes everything looks upscale.
author: Faye L.

description: Come for the happy hour on weeknights between 5-7 pm.  The oysters are $1 and you can order ~3 per person at a time.  It comes with a sweet chili sauce and lemons.  For beer you have several Asian options ranging from Chang's beer ($3.50) to the more pricier version of $5.  They also have other appetizers for around $8 such as tom yum dusted fries, crispy pork ears (interesting texture...), and some kind of sausage.  I have been here a few times, mostly for happy hour.  The regular dinner prices are quite pricey.  I ordered the Pad Mee Lao, which was $18 for some noodles!  I guess that is the SOMA price.  Definitely recommend coming for the happy hour.
author: Richard L.

description: If you come here for lunch on a weekday, make reservations in advance! Otherwise, there's a wait. I got the basil chicken and it was amazingly delicious--would get it again, plus I loved the colorful plates. A great Instagram location, and my leftovers were exciting to eat.
author: Patricia P.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because the Pad Mee was oh-so addicting.

   ---   ---   ---

I was in charge of picking a lunch spot during a work conference in SF, so obviously we picked a place that uses Yelp Reservations! I've also never seen a business pour more love and effort into their Yelp page than Lao Table. In addition to utilizing Yelp Res, they have a ton of business-uploaded photos and even offer pickup through Yelp Eat24! 

While scanning the menu, I changed my mind a few times on what I was ultimately going to order. I initially wanted to eat light and was eye-balling the salads, but none of them were hitting the spot in my mind, so I opted for the Pad Mee, which I don't think I've ever had before, so I didn't know what to expect.

The result? I'm officially addicted to Pad Mee after one experience, and will definitely be seeking it out in the future. The noodles were razor thin, but packed so much flavor. I think there was definitely some sugar mixed into this meal because the noodles were pretty sticky and had a hint of sweetness. Their Thai Tea was delicious as it usually is, but even had a slight bit of foamy-ness to it at the top.

Despite not even being very hungry going into this meal, I came away super impressed and in love with a brand new dish!
author: Brett N.

description:
Because this place is so close to work, I thought nothing of this place. But after coming 3-4 times, every time, the food was solid! I think it's better than most of the Thai places in the city! It is slightly pricier but worth it. 

Recently got the garlic pork with pepper I believe. The egg is a nice touch. Last time, I got the pho and it hit the spot. Very filling and large portions. 

Credit to the imperial rolls too. Nice and light with vermicelli noodles. Not hard or dense. 

Great lunch spot for a work meetup!
author: Young Y.

description:
We celebrated Mother's Day 2018 here. Right when you walk-in, you'll be impressed by its cool ambiance. We ordered 4 drinks, Lao beer, Lao Soda, pineapple billionaire and Smile Buffalo. All 4 drinks were pretty good! The smile Buffalo is the hardest of 4 drinks. We also ordered 3 appetizers. Chicken Satay, garlic chicken wings and the Lao Sausages. All 3 were excellent! For our main dishes, I ordered the fish garden which is meant to be a sharable appetizer. It's a make your own lettuce wrap with deep fried Tilapia. It comes in a tray where it displays the big crispy fried fish, all the veggies (lettuce, mint, cilantro and other herbs). 2 different sauce and It also comes with beef jerky, chicken Satay and beef cubes. Small portion of sticky rice and noodles came with it also.
My husband ordered the pork rice bowl with fried egg. My son ordered the pineapple fried rice, my daughter ordered the pork belly and her boyfriend ordered the shrimp curry with lychee! All were delicious! For dessert, we tried the Mango Mark which is mango sticky rice with shaved mango ice cream and we also order the chocolate suffle with Thai ice cream. To finished the night I had an americano. All these came at a whopping $350 but so worth it!
author: Luciene B.

description: Oh Lao Table, the very bad choice of music just ruined the ambience and Our dining experience.  A very loud music on a Monday night just doesn't make any sense. Food and service were both decent. We had the Spicy eggplant and tofu with basil which exceeded my expectations. The eggplant was tender and the tofu has a very meaty texture. The Kurobuta pork rice bowl with chili sauce could need some improvement. Although it was seasoned with the perfect amount of spice I suggest that they brine the pork to make it a little tender because it was very chewy. I was tempted to order the Mango sticky rice for dessert but the server honestly told me that they have some bad and sour Mangoes that evening (I really appreciate the honesty) Will I ever dine again? Maybe.
author: Maryann P.

description:
Review is for Happy Hour only which runs Monday through Friday 5pm to 7pm. 
We were looking for some pre-Giants game oysters and light eats for Happy Hour and decided on Lao Table. First thing you'll notice when walking in is how colorful and vibrant the interior is set up. The colors and decorative pieces throughout are just beautiful. I only wished the thoughtfulness behind the interior would translate to their menu offerings. If you're just here for the HH $1 oysters, I would specifically request a bar area seat as this offer is valid only in this section. This is not a cool thing to enforce and not make obvious in their signage. We primarily stuck to the HH menu and ordered quite a few small dishes to share. 

The standouts for me were the french fries(seasoned with a spicy kick), and beef jerky. The wings were decent but not a good value. I tried their Lao-jito(Mojito clone) which was pedestrian. I also tried their Old Fashioned off the regular drink menu and it was solid. The primary reason we ventured out here before the Giants game was to chow down on $1 HH oysters and these too were a disappointment. They were of the larger variety and not the best quality. Definitely not Kumamoto oysters(far from it).

Again I did not try their dinner menu so my rating truly only applies to my take on the HH experience here, and for that, I would not return again. Truly there are other better nearby options for HH oysters.
author: Dennis W.

description: We had gotten the top choice on the noodle list (the first one). It was a bit pricier than one would expect for two dollar signs, but the portions were big enough to split, so it all works out. If I were to knit pick, I would say the music choice is a bit odd, and slightly too loud, detracting from the general ambience of the joint.
author: Joel O.

description:
So, Laotian food is like Thai food with less spice? That's the impression I got. 

Lao Table seems to be catering to the business lunch crowd with a classy, lounge-like ambiance, and pricey entrees. I was more impressed with the ambiance than the food, so if you are just needing to wow guests with a sleek, sexy interior, or want to grab a fancy drink at the bar Lao Table will do. It's very pretty. 

Food-wise, our dishes were nice & well presented, but portions were small for the price, and flavor was lacking in most things I tried. I added the spicy condiments to everything! They're not into menu substitutions, and will charge you an extra $5 to change just about anything. The highlight of the meal was sipping my fresh young coconut ($7). They even let me take it home so I could eat the "meat" later. 

Worth a try if you're in the neighborhood and price isn't an issue.
author: Nique F.

description: So we had a later evening dinner here with a random assortment of rascals and roustabouts, some from work and others outside. It was during a big work conference in town so we all had healthy shares of spirits and beer before we ate. As such, I don't have a lot of specifics on the meal, being fortunate enough to not having paid the bill and not therefore not having an expense receipt. By memory I will say we had some simply outstanding Laotian fare here. The only really big miss was a large octopus appetizer because it was over cooked and rubbery. The service was pretty good considering the crowd. I wholeheartedly recommend this place.
author: Vasanth B.

description:
1 word: Delicious! 

Appetizer: Moo Nam Pla (the fried pork belly)
My order: Gai Yaan Ka-Min (chicken with turmeric and sticky rice)
Hubby's order: Spicy Steak Lao (Super jelly of Hubby's order) 

Although to me it seems a bit overpriced when I could just make the food at home myself, but I had to remind myself that we came here for the ambiance which has a very romantic feel to it (we came for our anniversary). The food was well made, the servers are amazing, and the ambiance is great. I will definitely be coming back!
author: Lisa C.

description:
It was 12:50pm...I had exactly 40 minutes to order my lunch, pick it up, eat it, and be back ready to continue on with my work conference. And it you've ever been to SF, or more accurately, SOMA, during the lunch hour, you know that accomplishing the above can be hit or miss. Food carts and windows can pull in lengthy lines, restaurants can get crowded...all lunchy hell can break loose. 

I put in trust to Yelp's pick up option and ordered up a basil chicken rice bowl from Lao Kitchen. The estimate was 10-30 minutes for the meal to be ready but thankfully once I placed the order, I was given an update time of 1:06pm to pick up my order. SCORE.  I bounded over, a few minutes early, and waited at the bar for my take out. Easy peasy. 

Once I dove into my lunch, my happiness continued. My rice bowl was more than plentiful (and thankfully so at $18+) - I could have made this into two lunches. There was a bountiful amount of ground chicken, a lovely fried egg, plenty of veg and the perfect amount of rice. Word the wise - this dish packed some serious heat. Not an uncomfortable amount of heat, but plenty of spice to kick my day up a notch.  Keep your beverage near, my friends. 

Flavors were great, portions were generous, and my lunch mission was accomplished.
author: Nicole W.

description:
With the prices from this place I was expecting more. More food, more service, more spice, more everything.

This place does have some ok prices, but the majority of menu items are like $15+ which for dinner ok, but lunch not so much. My bowl of $20 beef rib soup wasn't a cauldron like i was expecting and the beef on the bone in the soup made it a little bit hard to eat. The broth itself packed a flavor punch, but sadly the beef itself was ok.

A few of my coworkers wanted to substitute the proteins in their dishes and it was $5 surcharges. Prawns in lieu of chicken and chicken instead of tofu. 

The lao sausage as an app was delicious as was the spring roll. So, yay for appys!

Service was pretty non-comittal. Not too attentive.

The space itself is nice and large, so potentailly a good spot for those power corporate group lunches. Overall, not the biggest fan, but a solid option if you're not paying.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
We had a group reservation for lunch here this past week and we were all pretty excited to see what had replaced Osha Thai. Upon entering the restaurant I'd say the new owners have done a great job with the renovations and interior. It's a large space decorated in Laotian flare and I can't say I'd ever eaten Laotian food before so, I waited in anticipation. I mean, I waited a while for our server...

For my main, I ordered the spicy eggplant and substituted the tofu for chicken (which cost $5 bucks). The end result was eh, and for a $24 dollar dish at lunch! Everything was cooked well but, it lacked flavor. Overall, the dish was pretty muddled and bland, including the side of rice it came with. 

Will I be back? Me thinks not. It's clear that they have massive overhead and rent is probably killing the management. Hence the $20+ lunch plates. Welcome to the new San Francisco.
author: Benjamin F.
