description: Super awesome place to get a drink after work (happy hour very reasonably priced). What I love about this restaurant is the way the dishes are plated. The minced meet lettuce wraps were worth getting but not as a meal but a shared appetizer!
author: Sara L.

description:
This is more of a 3 1/2 star review. My lunch experience was better than "A-OK" but not quite "Yay! I'm a fan" and "I can't wait to come back."

I came here for lunch the other day with co-workers. It was pouring rain outside, but thankfully, Lao Table was walking distance from our office. The restaurant interior is a beauty. It had a cozy, modern-Asian decor, and judging by the diners, it looked like a hot spot for FiDi/Techie types. 

Unfortunately, looks can be deceiving, as we would soon find out. There are some serious service issues here. After being seated, it took almost ten minutes to get our menu or a glass of water. The hostess finally noticed that our table was being neglected and came back with our menus. I mean, that stuff happens. It's a new restaurant. They're still working out their kinks. No biggie. Our server took our order five minutes later. Not exactly the warmest waiter I've ever encountered. He didn't really provide too much insight into the menu or offer any recommendations. When a few of my co-workers asked if they could substitute chicken for prawns or another protein, our server simply replied, "No, that'll cost you another $5." It felt more like a penalty as opposed to a surcharge. It just left us all feeling a bit cold and confused. 

I will say this... the menu boasts an eclectic array of Laoatian dishes. There are a number of things I was interested in trying. Our table wound up splitting a few apps, including the Vegeterian Spring Rolls (with a garlic dipping sauce), and the spicy Lao Sausage. Both were quite delicious, and great to share with a group of 4 or 5 people.

For my entree, I chose the Basil Chicken (wok fried chicken, chili, garlic, basil, fried egg, over rice). The dish was fine, though not entirely memorable. I found some of the chicken pieces to be especially tough and hard to chew. And you really had to dig down to the bottom of the bowl with your fork to pick up the sauce. Even though they give you a generous serving, $17 still seemed a bit pricey (especially when you can get this kind of dish at most Thai restaurants for $12).

Lao Table offers a variety of beers, wines by the glass, and cocktails... but I decided to just stick with water since it was a work-day. 

Long story short... I would def give this place another shot. I think they're still new and working things out in the kitchen and on the floor. Given the high prices, I might just consider Lao Table for a SOMA happy hour (order a few apps to share and some cocktails).
author: Kevin B.

description:
Came here for small bites and drinks with a friend. We got here pretty late, around 8:30, on a Thursday night, and didn't have to wait. 

We split the calamari ($14.95) appetizer. It was okay, but I didn't read the description carefully and was surprised to that it was grilled and not coated in batter and fried. It was still good though.

For my drink, I don't remember which one I ordered (might have been the Hemingway Variation), but it was served in a giant metal pineapple which I've never seen before. The drink itself was very fruity; I couldn't taste the alcohol at all.

And finally, we ended on their mark mango dessert ($12). I love anything mango, and this dessert was the whole reason I wanted to come here. I had seen in pop up on my yelp newsfeed and was immediately intrigued by this mango shaved ice + mango sticky rice combo.

The dessert came with a container of condensed milk and mango juice. The mango juice is for the shaved ice, so you can pour it over the inner parts of the ice that have less flavor, and the condensed milk is for the mango sticky rice. I didn't like the consistency of the shaved ice that much, as it wasn't as light as I'm used to, but the mango flavor was still really good. The mango used in the mango sticky rice was ripe and yummy! Thank goodness they didn't use an unripe mango.

Overall, I thought the food and drinks here were decent.
author: Dianna H.

description:
As rich as San Francisco cuisine scene is, we've been missing a great Laotian restaurant, and this might just be it!
Attentive staff, intensely flavorful food, well presented cocktails.

The menu was so overwhelming with choices, a Laotian food noob like me needed guidance in ordering.
 
Loved the crispy sticky rice salad, especially because I don't eat salad and it came with a few leaves of lettuce. 10/10 would recommend. 

Tom Yum tastes like it should, expect it to be on the sour side with a little kick.

Me Ka Ti was too sweet for me, texture was good though. 

F-Lao'r, the mezcal cocktail was also a bit too sweet, not very balanced. 

I'd come back.
author: Châu B.

description: Great ambiance and good food! The tables are super close though, you almost feel like you are having dinner with strangers on either side.
author: Nikita N.

description: I was super impressed with the quantity and quality of food. My friends and I made a reservation on a weekday for a party of 7. I love ordering basil eggplant chicken, but there was only basil eggplant tofu. Strangely, the waiter insisted that they would not be able to sub chicken for tofu, so I had to order the chicken basil bowl with eggplant added. Luckily there was no extra cost. In the end, the bowl was a delicious choice - it came with a perfectly fried egg and was so flavorful without being overwhelming. The portion was probably big enough for me to eat over two meals, and I was stuffed afterwards. My friends also had great things to say about their food. I would definitely come back again for a filling and warming meal!
author: Hali M.

description:
Beautiful trendy looking restaurant, BUT the absolute WORST pho I've had ever! The broth was like water! There was no hoisin sauce or chili sauce, just siracha to add flavor. For $20!!! There should be some flavor!
Now maybe this is different when you dine in, but this was terrible. And a waste of money!
author: marie w.

description:
The space here is trendy and loud with lots of groups packed in and pop music pumping through the speakers. We had a bit of a difficult time hearing our friends across the table from us at times.

As others have noted, the service leaves something to be desired - our server disappeared for long periods of time, and we waited quite awhile after we were done to get the bill.

In contrast to what others have said, my wife and I both thought the food was pretty mediocre. We ordered the fresh spring rolls, chicken satay, garlic pepper pork, and the pineapple-fried rice. All of the dishes were pretty meh and we won't be back.
author: Andy W.

description: Lao Table was formerly one of the many Osha Thais in the city and I've heard from my coworkers that the interior and menu didn't change too much. The food tasted great but was definitely on the pricier side for what it was. But let me tell you, their drinks are AMAZING. I would definitely come here for the drinks which really sounds weird but I think the drinks were executed really well. I came here for a work lunch and the entire restaurant filled up which was so unexpected. However, they had only 2 servers and seemed short staffed. Also, the kitchen messed up our vegan/vegetarian option which was not really okay...a little more TLC from the restaurant would be nice since IMHO, an establishment should try to accommodate for all their patrons' special dietary needs. Thankfully it wasn't something deadly like a peanut allergy. I ordered the duck larb for my main entree and it was ON FIRE. That was so spicy and ya girl can handle her spices. It took us over 20 minutes to get the bill which was a bit stressful since we all had to head back to work afterwards.
author: Denise L.

description: Went for lunch. Gets very busy quite quickly, but not sure why. Seems overpriced for what is served. Nothing that spectacular, whether it is their plating, service, or food. It's all decent and the ingredients seem to be of good quality.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Love the food and ambiance. The interior is beautiful. Even the restroom is nice. We came here for my birthday dinner. Table for 9. We ordered a variety of items from the menu. All the foods were unique and delicious. There wasn't any that was bad. We had papaya salad; lao sausage (must get); spicy eggplant; mixed vegetables; prawns curry; basil ground chicken with basil & red bell peppers rice bowl (must get); garden fish fried whole tilapia came with chicken & beef skewers and beef jerky; pineapple fried rice; khaw kai noodles; and tomahawk steak (must get). Everything was tasty and so good. We also ordered cocktail drinks. Service was great. We were so full. Didn't order any desserts. However, it was one expensive dinner. In the mid-hundreds. We arrived at 7:30pm and left at 9:30pm. Overall, everyone enjoyed dinner and loved the food experience. It was a nice birthday dinner. We will definitely be back and won't be ordering this much again.
author: Amy H.

description: Honestly everything U've had here id amazing. I've had they Pork belly and pork knuckle. Everything is amazing. My favorite thing is their $1 oyster. It is changing my life and dream about it. Also the decor, ambience and music is very cool, very chill. I will be here every week for sure. Thank you Lao to be in San Francisco Soma.
author: Ben C.

description: Came here with a group of 10 friends and without even waiting, we got a table (though the place was packed and it was a Firdaus night). Service was a bit slow however; food came at various times, and I recieved mine ten minutes after my last friend's although we all ordered similar things. I got the pork cheek salad, which was great albeit the dressing was a bit spicy. The pork cheek was grilled perfectly. Portions are huge too which makes up for it.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Amazing Thai food with a Laotion twist! Came here on a Saturday night with two friends after making a reservation through Yelp. The atmosphere is very hip and modern, and the place was  pretty packed. 

We started off with Thai iced tea and ordered larb zeen beef lettuce wrap, me ka ti, pad pha beef, and lao fried rice. The prices seemed a bit high, but it was so much food we couldn't even finish! 

The lettuce wrap was incredible and such a large portion for an appetizer! The ground beef was perfectly spiced and you have a plethora of herbs and veggies to wrap the meat in. 

The me ka ti was also a winner. It comes out with all the ingredients separated. The server then pours and mixes the chicken curry onto the noodles and mixes it in front of you. 

Pad pha beef was good but tasted pretty standard. It's hanger steak cubes wok-fried with veggies and oyster sauce.

The lao fried rice had a nice spicy kick to it! It also came with fried chicken wings, which were good but nothing really special. 

Overall, this was a great experience and I would definitely recommend it to anyone in the area!
author: Sophie P.

description: This place steals! AVOID. AVOID. I was overcharged and, when I noticed and called out the error, the response I got was "we do not understand how to fix in system." Then, the table next to us noticed the same problem with their bill and were told the same thing. If you like getting ripped off, come to this place. The food is below average Thai food at a premium price. Actually, you'll pay more than premium price when you look at your bill! Also, there is a strange woman who followed us around. I think she tried to be the host, but had no clue what to do. So weird. Seriously, terrible.
author: Bryan C.

description: My favorite Thai food forever. Tom Yam Gong soup is the best. Lamb curry was heavenly tasteful. The lamb melts on your tongue. Will keep going back!
author: Charmie L.

description: Large group for dinner was handled well by hostess and waitstaff. Decor is appropriate, not over the top, and lighting is good. Flow of space around the tables is well designed and I didn't get a sense of crowding. As for the food, it was great all around. My fave was the curry dish (chicken or beef). One of the fried rice dishes, I don't remember which one, was a little salty, but that might be how it's supposed to be made? Staff seemed happy to be there so that's always nice to see. Their attentiveness indicated either great initiative or that the owner was around. That's always good.
author: Ichor B.

description:
Maybe this review is irrelevant for non-pork eaters but if you are a porkavore like me, this place is oinktastic. 

I was leery that this was going to be just a made over Osha Thai with Laotian food,  but it is waaaaay more. For the price , this place has was way better atmosphere and service than any peer restaurant and that's not even getting to the best part, the food.

Their pork knuckle and pork belly are hands down the best pork I've had in SF (they use the same sauce, the knuckle is bigger and has tasty skin, but I prefer the more delicate belly). The basil chicken was juicy and fragrant and  rice noodles are flavorful but delicate at the same time. The spring rolls are crisp, not greasy and packed with tastiness. And of course, that mango sticky rice is as good as I've had anywhere and the accompanying massive mango shave ice will stuff you silly. Portion sizes are more than generous and unless you want to be rolled out of the restaurant, best to box some for home. 

Not the cheapest southeast Asian food you can get at ~$35 pp after T&T (no booze). But it blows overrated places like Kin Khao out of the water. 

OINK.
author: Snuffles B.

description: AHHMAZINGGGG!! This restaurant is wonderful. The vibe is trendy and unique. We ordered the big Thai iced tea with jelly and it was good. We loved how big it was. My friend and I also shared the wrapped spring rolls, which is a must have! Be sure to wrap them in the lettuce and mint. It adds so much to it! The banana salad was deliscious ! So fresh and tasty. The red curry chicken was perfectly balanced between the tanginess and the coconut milk. The chicken was a little tough, and would have been better if it was pull-apart, but it was still yummy. We also ordered the mango dessert with the shaved ice, and mango sticky rice. So good! We loved it all so much and I already recommended all of my friends to come here! You won't regret it!
author: Taylor C.

description:
I have to say this was one of my first Laotian and best Thai place. Take your pick as to what you want to call it. Very nice decore. High ceiling. Clean. Definitely higher end than most places. The price was a little higher than most. The portions are generous and made up for the price.  Friendly and attentive service. The menu was familier yet still had enough new twists to make me excited about what not to expect. I would say the dishes had a little more flavor and spiciness  than the traditional Thai without  specified spiciness level.  The fried roll was crunch and very flavorful. 
Beef with a pepper corn dish with light sauce was excellent. I would reduce the amount of pineapple and add some scallions and mushrooms.  Their equal to Pad Thai with shrimp  was very good.  The noodle was fresh, not sticky or over cooked.  We finished our lunch with a chocolate shuffle with slices of mango, strawberry, liche and Thai ice tea ice cream.  The shuffle was sub par. It tasted more like a prematurely cooked softer  Browny.  However the company of fruit and ice cream made the difference. 
I would definitely recommend LAO Table.
author: S. K.

description: Pros: Tasty food, easy to get a table for a large group, and a decent cocktail list, especially if you like cocktails on the sweeter side. Great go-to for work lunches.
author: MJ C.

description:
I always used to come here when this was previously branded as Osha Thai, but with all the Thai food we have access to around us, it's been a welcome sight to now see a new Laotian restaurant in the mix. 

This place perfectly caters to the FiDi lunch crowd, and has prices that take advantage of those dining on their companies' dime. (Would you really pay $44/pp for a drink and some lunch?) Luckily for me, I fell into this category as my boss treated us to lunch here. I therefore enjoyed this business lunch very much! 

We ordered the fried rice, which had a spicy kick to it, noodles (which were very, very similar to Osha Thai's Phad Thai), mixed veggies, and the Mark Mango! 

Coming from a guy who tells everyone he's obsessed with mango, the bright yellow dessert was really delicious and fun to eat. It's a tower of shaved ice served with a pitcher of mango juice, another of condensed milk, all to be mixed in with fresh mango and sticky rice. YOM. 

Would I come back here on my own dime? Probably not. Is the menu full of tastiness and over-the-top desserts? It sure as heck is! If you have a little extra to spend on what would otherwise be a cheap Laotian/Thai meal, definitely don't be afraid to give this place a shot!
author: Stephen D.

description: A bit pricey for the non-happy hour items but found the portions surprising big for SOMA prices. Recommend going for the happy hour which is everyday from 5-7 for the $1 oysters! For the price, they are decently sized and pretty tasty and served with a delicious sweet Asian chili sauce. One downside is you can only order 6 at a time but they typically don't run out and are more than happy to provide another round. Service is great, hostesses are very friendly and nice. Good stop if you need a quick snack/dinner after work downtown.
author: Kristy L.

description:
This place is fantastic! I would highly recommend you come and try this place out if you're in the SOMA/downtown San Francisco area.

My group (of about 7) came in around 6:30pm last night. At that time, the restaurant was pretty empty. The waiters were quick to take our drink orders and initial food orders. 

Our drinks and appetizers came out pretty fast. We ordered the oysters and they were arguably the best oysters I have ever tasted. Their happy hour special until 7pm has $1 oysters by the way. 

The food here is excellent too! I personally ordered the garlic pepper pork. It comes with a fried egg, a good portion of pork and some rice. Tasted delicious and I was stuffed.

Now, what really sets this place above the rest is their mango shave rice/ice dessert that they have. It's a heaping mountain that's SO GOOD.

All in all, great restaurant, great ambiance, and great dessert!
author: James D.

description:
If I were to solely rate the food, it's pretty damn 4-star good (minus the spring rolls). But given you're paying an arm and a leg for just spring rolls alone, I wouldn't come here unless it was with a group of people or company-sponsored (for which it was).

Yes, I understand the location is what's driving the cost of $12 spring rolls, but I was utterly disappointed at them. Maybe it's because I still have $1 (amazing) spring rolls from Southeast Asia anchored to my mind, but there was nothing fancy about these spring rolls (given I used to be somewhat of an amateur spring roll maker myself).

Enough about the spring rolls. We also tried the Spicy Steak Lao ($30) and Kurobuta Pork Belly ($26), which were both mouthwatering and left an impression. Highly recommend those two dishes if you're looking at entree options.

This isn't your typical hole-in-the-wall but consider it fine dining for Laotian food. And deciding to go to Lao Table will depend on the setting. Company-sponsored? Sure! Date? Ideal! But if you're just craving some good Laotian/Thai food for a good price and you're just with your buddies, this isn't the place for you.
author: David W.

description: I really wanted to love this place. Cute decor. Nice menu. A few interesting cocktails. Unfortunately the stir fry noodle dish I ordered was bland which may have been because they made it gluten free (without soy sauce) for me. Perhaps in trying to be helpful they did themselves a disservice and they should have directed me to another, more flavorful dish. Otherwise the service was fine. They even replaced my drink quickly when a bug flew into it. For 2 drinks and 2 entrees, $100 (inc tip) seemed pricy.
author: Robin N.

description: This was our first time here. We had the red chicken curry & the scallops. Both were very flavorful. The crew was great!
author: Frank S.

description:
Was going to give this place at least a 4-star rating, but after coming to this place the 3rd time, we found a hair in the Red Curry. The server was apologetic, he even took it off our check. But no amount of apologies or money would take the grossness out of me. But hey, that's just me!

But the food is amazingly delicious here, they have lots of vegetarian (vegan) options. And better, they understand when I say vegan/vegetarian, which means no fish oil or shrimp sauce or even no eggs. 

- Love the red curry (of course until finding the hair). 
- Pad Thai equivalent here is "Pad Mee LAO" that's a decent option too.
- Rice Bowl - Basil (vegetarian) is very good. Good mix of veggies, spice, and rice. 
- Side Papaya Salad is amazing!
- Thai Iced Tea is good too!

Lastly, and by no means the least, the presentation is excellent. Plates, bowls, and glasses are classy and refreshing! 


All in all it's a good place, but just had to knock off two stars because of the hair incident.
author: Krunal G.

description: I have to give this place 2 stars. So most places have fixed menus on Valentine's Day, so that's totally fine. Usually you'd see some kind of note or something on their website page or Yelp page. I was really excited to try this place out since I love South East Asian food. So I made a reservation through Yelp for dinner, which happen to be on Valentine's. About 3 hours before the reservation, I get a phone call from the restaurant to confirm the reservation. I say of course. Then she proceeds to tell me that there is a fixed menu of $65 dollars per person. I was like wait what? Now you tell me? I was looking for a $100+ dinner for two that night. So I ended up canceling the reservation online through  Yelp and of course it being Valentine's Day, way too hard to find a place to eat. At the very minimum, call the day before please or maybe have an update on your website.
author: Julie L.

description: My new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Everything was delicious and the service was great too.
author: Ann H.

description: Everything is pricey, but everything is good. They box leftovers up for you, which is classy. But they're sloppy about it so you end up gnawing on giant pork knuckle leftovers at work without any of the rice or sauce, which isn't classy.
author: tianyu l.

description: Super pretty location and nice staff. But the food is just not good and super pricy at that. We got some calamari appetizer that was not only rubbery but parts were so rubbery that they were inedible. I've never had hanger steak that was so chewy - I don't actually know how you can ruin hanger steak so badly. And the larb was just meh.  $66 for the 3. Two stars for atmosphere.
author: reza n.

description: Met a dear friend last week for a biz meeting. The restaurant was packed. We had a great dinner experience there. It's upscale and beautiful design restaurant. Food were great, authentic, delicious and beautiful presentation of Laotian food. The service was hand down thank you Khun Kitty ( Manager )  for a royal treatment and I'm a fan. Can't wait to come back
author: Katie E.

description:
******UPDATE: I have to update this review.  I really enjoyed the food and service but if you are using your credit card- DON'T.  Three of us got fraudulent charges on our credit card the following day. We narrowed it down to who used their credit cards where and it pointed to Laos.  So beware if you are using your credit card to pay. **** 

After finishing happy hour at Anchor and Hope around the corner for $1 Oysters, my friends and I stopped by the newly opened Lao Table to check out their Happy Hour since it ends at 7pm.  I must say it is a beautiful space- great job on the renovations!  (use to be Osha's Thai on 2nd Street) I've been here twice for the happy hour from 5-7pm.  I would like to try their dinner menu items soon as well.  

Some tasty bites we had were:
Chicken wings- you can't eat just one.  Must order multiple orders!
Heavenly beef- tasty beef jerky.
Fries- yummy!
Mango & caramel sauce- it's an acquired taste as it has fish sauce but i loved the sweet &   salty combo here.
Sausages- nice flavors
Vegetable Spring Rolls- deep fried goodness

Food was delicious and service was excellent.  Will definitely include this in my rotation of favorite places in the city to hop around too in the city!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Hands down! The very best food we had in the city. We came here for date night. Beautiful ambiance, lighting and mood were perfect. Very professional staff and so assertive. 

We ordered their crispy rolls for apps. These were the very best rolls I have ever had. You can taste every flavor and the freshness of it. 

Next was the sizzling scallops with the curry reduction. Oh my Gawd! It was like butter! I rolled my eyes with greatness for each bite. The flavors went harmoniously with each other!!

And for the grand finale, we ordered the crying tiger steak. (Medium) Wowzers!! One of the best steaks we have ever had!!! They seared it perfectly. It was seasoned and cooked with love! The food was sooooo delicious, I wanted to meet their chef just to give them the praise they deserve. Of course I didn't ask to meet them seriously but that is how amazing the food was! We will most definitely be back! 100 stars to you all at Lao Table! Thank you for making our date night that much more wonderful!
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I can honestly say I've (to my knowledge) not had Laotian food. This was part of the appeal for dining here. My boyfriend and I went in the other night around 9 PM. What I noticed immediately was the brightness of the space. It was well-lit (something we joked as a rarity nowadays) and the decor added to its vibrancy. At the center of the restaurant are these gorgeous red-magenta chandeliers. It's very festive and colorful throughout. 

For food, we ordered Lao Sausage which is served with chunks of fresh ginger, peanuts, and sliced garlic. The sausage really packed a punch. It was a bit spicy and had lots of robust flavors. You eat the slices of sausage with fresh romaine. I thought this was delicious. Similarly, the "Larb Zeen" beef lettuce wrap was spicy and quite fresh. It reminded me of a traditional Thai larb. Our favorite dishes of the night were the Garlic Pepper Pork Bowl and "Khaw Kai" Noodles. First, about the bowl: the pork was succulent and sat on a bed of rice. It was accompanied with a fried egg. When you break the yolk, it seeped into the rice making it extra silky and smooth. There were pieces of cucumber as well on the side. The intense flavors of the garlic coupled with the egg-rich rice reminded me of a traditional Filipino breakfast (e.g. tocilog, longsilog) except replace the cucumber with tomato. In other words, this garlic pepper pork bowl is great! The noodles were also tasty with an abundance of greens and lean chicken. We also ordered cocktails which were both a bit too sweet for our liking. Luckily our satisfaction with the food trumped our disappointments with the cocktails. Also, somewhat of a digression, but their plates and bowls are beautiful and uniquely-shaped. I want them! I looked underneath to find out where they got them; the lovely bowls are from Thailand.

In terms of value, I thought it was alright. The portions were generous but the prices were steeper than we expected. We suspect this had to do with its downtown location. We noticed a lot of the diners look like they were tech workers having a late dinner after work -- folks who generally have lots of disposable income. I also suspect this is popular with the business crowd during the workweek hence Lao Table's ability to price their dishes beyond expectation. Nevertheless, the food quality coupled with the ambiance is a 4-star experience. I'm no authority of Laotian cuisine so I don't know if they served up the most "authentic" food, but for what it's worth, this was a great introduction.
author: James Z.

description: Average food, lacking service, very expensive. Portion is big but for lunch be prepared to pay 20-30 dollars for bland dry meat and noodle. Servers don't greet, don't tend. They look like a grumpy underpaid bunch.
author: Dancing S.

description: We were there before 6:30, so the restaurant wasn't so crowded yet. It was packed by 7. My friend mentioned that it was Osha Thai before and I actually liked the food here better than Osha, lighter and less greasier.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I did not know this place was reopened by Osha Thai. This explains a lot, from taste to prices lol. Made a reservation through Yelp and it went smoothly. I arrived 10 mins early and they sat us down. They have happy hour from 5-7 at the bar only. You can't take away from the bar which is just annoying. $1 oysters is what people went for.

Service was ok. The waiter came to ask if I was ready to order but I said we were waiting for one more. Once I was ready, I told one of the waiters. He said ok, looked at me for a second, then walked away and never came back. Started serving other tables and even took the order of the table behind us. Like hello? After that, service (of another waiter) was much better. Waters were refilled and needs were met.

Here's the thoughts on food:
~Duck Wings - I felt it was a bit tough. There was 4 on the dish. There was some sauce at the bottom which made the wing taste better. Otherwise it's just fried wings. Couldn't really taste duck.
~Chicken Satay - 6 skewers in 1 order. Chicken was a bit dry but the peanut sauce made it all better.
~Grilled Calamari - this was something new. I liked the grilled part of the calamari. It's also soft not chewy which is how I like it. The sauce is pretty spicy tho just FYI.
++Totally Prawns - MY FAAAAAAVORRRRITEEEEE. Sweet pineapple red curry yum yum yum. This is exactly how I remember the Prawns Pineapple at Osha Thai. It's so good. It's a mild spicy too. The prawns are also huge on this dish. I felt like this place made it better than Osha themselves.
++Garlic Pepper Pork - Another favorite of mine. The pork was marinated well and tasted delicious. I would order this again.
+Pineapple Fried Rice - Not much to expect from a pineapple fried rice. Pretty standard stuff. I usually order it cuz pineapples.
+Lao Fried Rice - I love the fact that this dish comes with 3 chicken wings. It is VERY MILD spicy. Not too big of a fan of the chopped up green beans but meh. It's a good deal tho.
-Mok Seabass - This dish was weird. Like the herbs on top was spicy and I wasn't sure what I was eating. Seabass was a dry too. I didn't really like it and I would not recommend it.
-Pad mee Prawns - wasn't a memorable dish and I had it just last night. If I remember correctly, it was a bit bland.
author: Benita M.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the ambiance, service and especially food here! Had a great experience here. The restaurant has colorful loincloth walls and high ceilings with ambient bells. Servers were extremely friendly, helpful and prompt. Check in with us to see how we were doing.

The most important thing about the food is holy - moly this was AMAZING!!! We ordered Papaya Salad (Lao style) was tasty and a lot of sides. Tomahawk steak is pretty big but good for sharing and perfect cook, served with grilled sticky rice and "Jaew", the flavor was everything I wanted and so much more. and more interesting menus that I want to try next time. 

Can't wait to come back.
author: Oil L.

description: If you like to go to a club and try and eat your dinner then this place is for you. The food was pretty good, but the ambiance was AWFUL. They were playing LOUD techno music, blasting the AC and had terrible service. It was hard to enjoy my meal with the music and cold air blasting in my face. I would come back here for take out ONLY.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I had the mixed vegetable rice bowl during a lunch meeting for two. The place was packed Friday at 1 pm, but died down within the next 20 minutes. 

I've been here twice and both times was impressed with the flavor of my dishes. You can make most dish vegan, if that's your thing,  by asking for the vegetarian version and removing an egg. 

I'll be back.
author: Marlon G.

description: So good I had to have lunch here back to back .. food is extremely flavorful and tons of unique combinations.. you must try the Thai iced tea
author: Robert B.

description:
It was great!! I ate so many kinds of food. It was amazing. I want to visit again!!!
Especially, i like sour soup and beef steak. Try!!
author: YoungHo L.

description:
The restaurant has a trendy decor and I liked the look of the place. It got crowded for lunch on a weekday and I'd recommend a reservation.The staff did their job but wasn't especially helpful. 

 I'm not a Laotian expert so I can't tell you how authentic the food is. Here are my thoughts though. I ordered the pineapple rice bowl and it was massive!  I took a to go box which rarely happens. It had both chicken and shrimp but the chicken was a little dry (lots of though) and there were only two small shrimp. The flavor was good and it had a nice variety of vegetables. For $18 I'd expect it to be better. 
 
I went for lunch on a weekday and they use the same menu and pricing that the do for dinner. That makes lunch too pricey and too much food. In my option they should have a smaller portion lower priced menu for lunch but they were packed so why would they change.
author: Scott M.

description:
Came on a Monday night with my friend and we both got the khaw kai noodle. 

Service 5/5
Upon arrival, we were warmly greeted by the pretty hostess and was seated right away. Waitress super attentive the whole duration of the meal and came back frequently to check on us. Lots of smiles :D

Price 3/5
Service fee was embedded in the receipt even though we only had a party of 2. Ended up paying for $19 before tip for each Khaw kai. NOT WORTH.

Khaw Kai 3.5/5
Fab presentation. The taste of this dish mimics pad Thai but was not all the way there. For a simple noodle dish made with chicken, bean sprout, crushed peanuts and flat noodles, the price of $19 does not justify it at all 

Overall, I will only come back here if I'm treating someone out and if they really want Thai food. Otherwise, nahhhhhh
author: Michelle C.

description:
I ordered dinner from Lao Table tonight as I was craving some Thai food and this restaurant is within walking distance of my hotel. 

I ordered the Grilled Calamari, brown rice and a Thai Tea. 

The calamari was insanely delicious. Great grilled flavor and cooked perfectly without being over done. The brown rice was a step above regular. I'm not a big fan of brown rice but I've been on a huge work out kick lately and REALLY wanted that Thai Tea, so I picked brown rice over white. It was very, very good - just as good as white in terms of both texture AND flavor.

The Thai Tea was lovely - not too sweet and slightly bitter. Highly recommend.

Unfortunately the only drawback was they forgot to pack utensils and since I'm staying at a hotel, I had to wait 30 mins for room service to bring me utensils. I had to eat the food cold, but the fact that it was still delicious says a lot!
author: Naomi H.

description:
The server was foul tempered. The food was o.k. but overpriced

It was a bad choice as a place to bring a business colleague, you will see why in a minute

We ordered chicken with noodles and peanut sauce and an eggplant dish.  Both tasted pretty good. 

The problem was the service. It was very bad. We are pretty easy to please customers, so this is saying something. 

Despite the nice decor, the demeanor of the staff was more like an extremely low end chinatown greasy restaurant...think loud, harsh rude, stressed out, angry and impatient... and you will know what we experienced. 

Our server did a lot of scowling, frowning and barking. It seemed like she was angry at us the whole time we were there. 

Even though the restaurant was only 60 percent full, they were annoyed we didn't have a reservation, and were in an incredible rush to get us in and out. We actually were only in there for an hour, but the whole time, we felt like they just wanted to turn over the table and get the next person in.  

The server made an annoyed/fed up face when we didn't want drinks and dessert. 

My friend had a few questions about the dishes, because of his dietary restrictions and this also clearly really irritated the waitress. 

Next time we will go somewhere pleasant and gracious.
author: Rob O.

description: Mediocre food and really bad service. Very disappointed... It's one of those pretentious hip restaurants that have pretty plates but very average food. Service was bad too, waiters would straight up ignore you and bring you a second check when you've already gave them your credit card?!
author: Lu L.

description:
Stopped by for dinner on a Wednesday night. The restaurant ambience is nice, with a dining area and separate bar area with a few TVs that were playing sports games. We were seated immediately and the server came over often to check on us. We started out with drinks: the Lao Soda and Rye Manhattan were both really good (and decently strong) and the fresh coconut was a unique menu item.

The food selection was extensive and we had the Spicy Eggplant, Kurobuta Pork Belly, Pad Mee Prawn Noodles, and the Khao Nar Ped Honey Roasted Duck. The food arrived relatively quickly. Each dish was very flavorful and portion sizes were pretty large. 

I had a great overall experience and would definitely come back.
author: Esther W.

description: First time been here with friends, food was good, like their decor, will come back soon
author: Yueming G.

description:
I came here for Happy Hour.. 

They have OK oysters (well, it's $1 oyster so .. erh) 

Garlic chicken wings: it's good, 6 wings per order & it's 8$ 
Tom Yum Fries: we thought it would be more tasty than that.. but it tasted like normal fries . Nothing special. For $6? I would go for McDonald French Fries. (Please do not offer this as your happy hour - it's just sad) 

Coconut soup: My bf loved it even though they used pork ribs instead of seafood Thai Style. It wasn't my cup of tea at all. 

I dont dislike this place but I don't get excited about this place either. I'm sure it's my taste bud is being different.
author: Thao P.

description: Meh. The food was tasty, servers were really clueless, and for what it was, it was extremely pricey. There was a lack of vegetables in our curry and an extra (tiny) bowl of rice was $4. They were very quick with service and we did enjoy our app and it's a good spot for bigger groups of 6-10 people.
author: B L.

description: Prices slightly higher in the $$ range (around $15-$25) but the food was good and nicely presented. Service was also good and the place had a nice ambiance. I had the Mok Seabass which, if you are familiar with Malaysia/Singapore/Indonesian cuisine, is very similar to Otak Otak. It was delicious although I did think it was on the pricey side ($25) for the portion I received. Overall i liked the place and will return to try other dishes!
author: Claire S.

description:
Ist time here. We love everything from decorating to the foods. Highly recommended!
Tom Yum Koong - Tum Marg Hoong - Lao Sausage
Crying Tiger Steak
author: Co T.

description: It was totally random I saw the one dollar oyster happy hour. So I came in sat down and ordered oyster and coconut water. coconut was freshly cracked and it was so good. Even the coconut white was so fresh and tender. never had fresh coconut this tasty. The oyster was also great.
author: Joy W.

description:
Yikes! Can't believe this place has 4 stars! I found that despite being extremely pricy, the food was actually lower quality than Lao/Thai food I've had at other places for lower prices. Also the service was spotty. As just one example, we were not brought our check even after it was clear that we were finished, and after asking for our check it took 5+ minutes for it to be brought to us. Finally, this place is SUPER noisy. Don't expect to be able to hear your companions well, especially if they are soft speakers.

+ 1 star for the decor, which was fab.
author: Chelsea H.

description:
Great for business meal as it can get quite expensive. Also, spicy here is VERY spicy. Make sure you are realistic about your spice-levels.

I loved the following:
- crispy sticky rice salad
- duck wings
- papaya salad
- lao fried rice
- garlic pepper pork
- pho duck

Some dishes we got spicy, and it was so spicy that we were chugging Thai iced tea and wine to wash down the heat. It was totally worth it. 

We came for dinner during a weeknight and there was certainly no need to get reservations ahead of time.
author: Jackie W.

description:
By the same owners as Osha. I didn't know that when I came, but it makes sense. Ambiance and decor are on the posh side. Service is pretty solid. Food is good. I had bamboo salad, lao sausage, and the tom zaab lao. Quality of ingredients and overall flavor were pretty authentic. The dishes were on the drier / less oily side, if you compare them to similar dishes in Thailand. 

Price point here is on the pricer side. Bamboo salad is $12.95, sticky rice $4.50, Lao Sausage $13.95. Place is great for large groups and a great alternative to your stereotypical thai dinner.
author: James S.

description:
Yesterday night this place was packed. There were at least 15 or so people waiting during the dinner rush but thankfully we had a reservation. I would say it's better to do family style here so you can try more dishes. 

We ordered the veggie crispy roll, beef lettuce wrap, red curry chicken, spicy egg plant, pad mee and the pad moo-pa. Generally very flavourful and spicy.
author: Galen W.

description:
$$ is not quite right. It feels more like $$$$. It's probably more expensive than Kin Khao, which has 1 Michelin Star.

The menu is very similar to what it was like when it was Osha but it's even more outrageously expensive. We ordered three rice dishes to share for lunch: Basil Chicken ($16.95), Lao Fried Rice ($18.95), and Kobe Beef lunch special ($19.95).

The portions were relatively large and the best one by far was the Lao Fried Rice. It was a dark colored fried rice with minced chicken, hot basil, chicken wings, and a fried egg. It was very tasty and it's different from the other rice dishes.

I had high hopes for the Kobe Beef. It was pretty good but it only came with 4 strips of beef and some onions on top of a huge pile of rice. Not the best value.

The Basil Chicken was not that great. I'm personally not a fan of white meat chicken because it can easily become tough and chewy. This dish definitely suffered in that way.

We didn't get anything to drink and we each paid $25 for lunch. Lao Table is extremely overpriced but at least the food is ok.
author: Yi Z.

description: I absolutely loved this place! All the food was delicious and their happy hour is great. Make sure you come early for their oysters, they do run out! I tried their wings, beef jerky, fried calamari, squid, and papaya salad. I loved every dish! Their atmosphere is great and their service as well. I highly recommend this place!
author: Darby D.

description: We had a great dinner experience there! Although food price is high (financial district upscale), food and service quality are good! Try their happy hour menu(5-7pm)! 1 dollar oyster and some good quality drinks and appetizers!
author: Nina H.

description: A bit pricey. But debatably worth it perhaps. Nice ambience. Always busy. Online reservations are not always honored but they seemed overwhelmed the night I went. The food was good. Got the hot pot ramen which came with one of those 10 cent packets which is a little crazy since the dish cost $60! All in all, I would probably come back if someone else wanted to but not sure I would suggest it myself.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Brought a friend here for a birthday lunch (made a reservation; thanks Yelp Rez!) and realized when I walked in that I had last been here when it was another Thai restaurant-- although the decor changed a little, the general layout was still the same. 

Everything about our experience was great-- food was super-fast, seated immediately, big portions, etc. So why 3 stars? Sticker shock: for two entrees and an appetizer, I paid nearly $75! 

I couldn't notice a tangible difference in the quality of my food or fanciness of ambiance compared to several cheaper options in the area, although the spicy tuna appetizer stood out as especially delicious and not likely available elsewhere. 

I can't see myself returning other than for special occasions (like a birthday, as I had). But if you're feeling spendy or want to impress a client, this is a solid spot-- they had us in and out in 55 minutes (and we didn't feel rushed at all), which is the kind of efficiency most of the people in the area need on a weekday.
author: Krista L.

description:
Hands down date night food. I went with a friend and whilst enjoyable, we aren't rich enough to just keep having meals at these places just yet.

That said, very nice service (they mix your food in front of you for certain dishes), good portions, tasty and well spiced.
author: Michael C.

description: Have been here for both lunch and dinner and have not been impressed either time. The environment, decor and price tag all point to high quality thai food but unfortunately this place does not deliver. Many other great thai places in SF that don't prey on the wallets of financial districters. I'd pass on this one.
author: Marisa R.

description:
7/19/17: hands down, the BEST (Laotian) dining experience I've had in the US: beautiful and creative authentic ambiance, friendly staff, and amazing food. 

Mee Pad: delicious!
Miang Pla: freshingly tasty and healthy!

One of my new favorite restaurants in SF.
author: Ms. Edna T.

description: I will definitely visit again! The only con is the Tom Yum soup is a little bit spicy.
author: Sammi Z.

description: I've been here once; it is crowded lunchtime​, so be aware, and book in advance. Food is excellent, they have a ​bunch of vegetarian​ options. I'm not sure if​ this food authentic or not, but it's tasty. Also, portions are big enough, so you won't leave feeling hungry. I'd recommend checking photos on Yelp before ordering, as dish names don't tell me a lot.​
author: Dmytro Z.

description:
I think maybe we didn't order the right things.

Overall, my impression was that this place is more concerned with presentation of food than actual taste and quality.  The service was also very slow.  Very expensive and definitely not worth the price.

It was really cold outside, so as soon as we got seated I asked for hot tea.  It took 15 minutes, and flagging people down 2x to get my tea.  The tea was also $7 and came from a tea bag.  For that sort of price, I expect finer loose leaf teas.  The presentation was nice tho -- albeit not very practical?

I ordered the Me Ka Ti.  It's a rice noodle dish with a coconut sauce that's mixed at the table.  Presentation was lovely, but I think the dish isn't well thoughtout.  It's hard to mix the sauce in well, and the plate was cold, so even though the sauce was piping hot, the noodles ended up being cold.  And this was a very cold day where I was hoping for hot food. It also had this odd nutty metallic taste.  I ate until I wasn't hungry and then didn't take home the leftovers.

My partner had basil chicken.  Which he enjoyed.  Maybe I should have gone with a rice dish. 

Overall, it was ~$70 for two dishes, tea and an extra side of rice.  We won't be going back.
author: Christiana T.

description: The decor is very classy. We ordered Khao Nar Ped, Chicken Satay, Panang Lamb Curry, and Mango Sticky Rice. All the dishes were delicious. Prices were on the higher end. Service was a little slow. Overall, I would recommend this place for Laotian/Thai food.
author: William S.

description: What an amazing dining experience. I traveled to SF for business and stumbled upon this gem. Sat at the bar. The bar staff was super helpful in answering questions about the menu. I had a delicious F'Lao'R cocktail and amazing roasted duck rice dish. The fried pork belly was slightly over fried and a bit dry. But the chocolate soufflé cake was a delectable work of art.
author: Luba R.

description: Great place. Delicious food and fun atmosphere. Good presentation. Always have a great time there. Alcohol drinks are terrible though.
author: Chiao-Yu T.

description: Lao is delicious, there's no doubt about that, but something keeps it from being roll your eyes good. It is too mainstream? Too "clean"? Maybe. The menu is expansive and the presentation is gorgeous, with large bowls of flat rice noodles serviced in beautiful blue and white bowls on a wooden board, garnished with a fresh orchid. The grilled calamari appetizer is also visually stunning, whole, clean, and splayed open with a spicy vinaigrette. It's a great place to grab a company lunch in Soma, which is the typical crowd (it fills up fast at noon), but its prices prevent it from being a reliable takeout joint. Service is great, and you can make reservations through Yelp, so I highly recommend!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Came here for lunch with a girlfriend.  We got in a shared table for 4 around noon without a reservation.  The restaurant itself was pretty.  Menu had lots of choices.  

I was in the mood for beef because I had recently had shrimp curry.  I asked our waiter what beef dish he suggested and he told me the steak which was a bit pricey or the beef wrap dish. 

I ordered a lemonade (which was really delicious) it was sort of a lemonade mixed with sparkling water, a spritzer if you will.

The beef wraps came out and had a lovely presentation.  However, the flavor was just not there.  It tasted like someone just threw plain  crumbled beef pieces into a bowl with onions and hot chili's.  I asked for dipping sauce and they handed me a 4 pot side of hot sauces.  

Overall, very underwhelmed with this restaurant.  My girlfriend ordered a shrimp curry dish and also agreed it was a 2.5 or 3 star at best.  We won't be back.  Also, way more expensive than I expected.  It ended up being $25 a person.  I could find MUCH better lunch options in the area for that price.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Great food and ambiance.
Highly recommend "Tum Marg Hoong" delicioussssss!!!! The smells, the music, the atmosphere , the menu all amazing . Can't wait to come back here again. I love Everything here. Come back again soon
author: Yim B.

description: Absolutely love this place. Highly recommend the duck lettuce wraps, the tamarind beef and the mark mango as dessert. Also love the young coconut juice at this place.
author: Andrew S.

description:
If you're going to go that expensive comparatively, it should at least be 1) refined 2) elevated 3) tasty.  

Short version this does not have the authentic flavors of Thai or Laos.  

It's food for Americans - everything overly sweet, from the sauces to the tom yum- the nam prik pao had way too much sugar instead of tom yum having the aroma of lemongrass and kaffir lime it just tasted like sugar.  Nasty.

The coconut milk soup w/ beef short rib- the beef rib was cooked fine- the milk was used way too much.  Gross.  

Crispy pork?  Just crispy and relatively dry.  The jaow (jaew) sauce was tamarind and sugar, but it should have toasted rice too.  Didn't.  

Fried rice w/ crispy chicken wings- the wings were unsalted.  No taste.  Fry was fine.  Fried rice needed fish sauce, lime, fragrance of herbs, everything rather tasteless.

The flat noodles w/o soup, no taste of sweet soy sauce, white meat chicken super dry.

Ordered jasmine tea and they tried to convince me it was jasmine tea.  It was herbal tea instead (flowers in the bag).  Lady server walked off after I said this is not jasmine tea.  

Nothing was elevated (except the prices and a little decor), otherwise it was standard takeout food quality at much higher prices.  

None of the sauces popped, meaning low quality (tamarind, fish sauce) everything lacking umami.
author: J S.

description: My friend and I split a cocktail and a Thai ice tea, both were really tasty! The food was definitely good, but not mind blowing. However, everything on the menu looked fantastic and I can't wait to go back soon!
author: Riley J.

description:
So I made a reservation here for a lunch date with a friend and I must say I wasn't disappointed. It was our first time to go out on a lunch, so I wanted it to be great and this place turned out to be a good one. The ambience is good, I have a feeling its' better at night with those tea light candles on tables. The food is good too, do not order curries though. We ordered Miang Pla which was so much in quantity that I was half full by just eating that, it was delicious. I then ordered basil chicken rice bowl and it was good. The quantities of their meals are huge but then so are the prices. 

I am not sold completely due to the high prices. I have had equally good food at lower prices. That said, service was good and I might come back here, I just have to be prepared to pay extra. I would say, its' worth a try.
author: Ramyata M.

description: Trendy, overpriced, average food,  happy hour spot, for the FiDi and maybe a place for business lunches. It reminded me of where they all go after work on  Alley McBeal. won't be back.
author: Susan S.

description:
If you like Osha Thai, I recommend checking out Lao Table which was created by the same team from Osha! The interior of the restaurant is beautiful and is a great spot for a nice lunch with the team or for a meeting.

The plating of all the dishes was beautiful and they definitely put thought into making their dishes visually appealing. There are a lot of different options (curries, rice, noodles, etc.) on the menu but I did notice they didn't have vegetarian options on the menu. They did accomodate a request to sub veggies instead of meat for a curry dish though. It'd be nice if that was more visible on the menu.

I had the Khaw Kai noodles which were delicious and verrrry spicy- if you can't handle the spice, make sure you ask for less spice on this one.

They serve fresh coconut water out of real coconuts which is great but it does get really noisy since the coconuts are hammered open at the bar which is near the tables. It's definitely a 'nicer' lunch spot (think $16-$25 entrees) but worth it for a treat yourself meal!
author: Renu A.

description:
Lao Table has amazing food presentation. Everything that we ordered was like a mini show. However, the food was okay for the price. I ordered the beef pho, which was more like beef noodle soup. The soup flavor was slightly bland but the beef was perfectly tender. 

The service was great and the atmopshere had a comfortable feel. I could have stayed for hours staring at the details they had on the walls. 

Overall, I really enjoyed my visit but I don't think the food is worth the high price.
author: Helen Z.

description:
Good food, good portion, good service. 

They have some really good Asian fushion items
author: William C.

description:
Came here again, my favorite on the 2nd Street.  I tried something new:
- the spring roll is very unique, different from the Chinese and Vietnamese versions.  The sauce is yummy.
- the beef with egg plants is tasty.  The egg plants soak the juice of the beef and sauce
- mango desserts is irresistible.  The sticky rice makes the mango ice interesting with a good taste and a chewy mouth feel.  it has generous portion good for 2-3 people.  I can only get the mango desserts like this here.
author: Flora Z.

description:
I've been here once and it left such a bad impression that I'll likely never return. I live and work a couple blocks away so I was hoping for something stellar.

Pro's: decor and service are both really great. No faults there.

Con's: pricey for what you get. I ordered the pho, which was over $20, and it was terrible. Easily the worst pho I've ever had. Given that it's not a Vietnamese restaurant, I may try another dish in the future and update this review but... I felt completely ripped off for what was on the menu with such a heavy price tag. I wouldn't order it again if it was free, to be honest. It was that bad.
author: Mike W.

description:
We've basically been here several times and this review is extremely delayed. We've ordered a variety of funky things (because one of us gets homesick for these foods) so you're not going to see this review for their fried rice, sautéed veggies, or pho but here we go...

Service along with papaya salad is hit or miss. Service is very friendly and accommodating but it sometimes gets understandably busy so we have to flag them down at times. 

Go for the tum mak hoong/papaya salad - it'll be what you see at most Thai places. Super mild with great flavors and a great intro for most. If you want to veer off the norm or if you like things super spicy, then ask for the Lao style salad. We warned you about the spiciness though (you can also ask for less spicy)! We also ask for less sugar and they're extremely accommodating. Thumbs up for being so gracious about our particular order - it can be a pain sometimes so it's much appreciated.

Sup nor mai was not as flavorful and was much more sour than expected. Don't order unless you really like bamboo and fish notes obviously. 

Khao poon was okay but not enough curry soup like traditionally prepared (maybe should've ordered me ka ti instead?) so it was more like a mee lard nah (drunken noodles with gravy) instead of khao poon. 

Mok seabass is something you should definitely try. It's a delicious banana leaf wrapped fish with herbs and they do it well here. It's light and aromatic; similar to how many other cultures wrap stuff in banana leaves and the French prepare poisson en papillote. 

Get the crispy sticky rice salad. Just get it. It's good stuff and a usual crowd pleaser.

Gai yaang ka min is perfectly spiced and typically good. The chicken pieces were sometimes too fatty or undercooked during our later visits but still alright. 

The moo nam pla was okay. Standard pork belly but get it with Lao Lao and jeow bong for a well rounded meal. 

Very cool to see more Lao/Thai Isaan places in the city and to see their take on these classic dishes in addition to having khao neow on the menu. I still think if you're looking for authentic Lao food, head to sac, Stockton or Oakland. Great fusion and intro to Lao cuisine for the SF population. The new interior is beautiful and the service is super friendly. Great for big groups or date nights. Only been here for dinners and will probably come back...because one of us got the other hooked on the Lao style papaya salad :)
author: Meli.Lars M.

description: Great service,  crunchy rice salad was great.  Not a fan of their version of "pad thai" because it was very sweet and not the typical pad thai flavors.  Also noodles were thin.  Very very nice interior decor n ambiance.  Worth the price I'd say.
author: Kristine N.

description:
We had a fantastic lunch here. The Laos Fried Rice is super tasty. Portions are pretty big here.

I'd definitely come again here.
author: Evert P.

description:
Terrible service, I'm rating the service alone. For the quality and price of food they serve, I would imagine they would be well staffed and funded. They were under staffed on a Friday night during prime dinner rush. The host didn't even know where the reservation tablet was, and there were several people booked for reservations at the same time when there weren't any tables available. It's more of an issue with management, the servers were rude and very discombobulated as a result of the disorganization. 

Adjust your reservation system! Hire more staff! 

We left after 20 minutes waiting for a table, then 20 minutes waiting for water after two different servers asked us what we would like to drink. This was with a dinner reservation.
author: Amy R.

description: The food was just so so, though my fried rice for the 2nd visit was below the average. Would be 5 stars for location and services, while 2 stars for food quality
author: Darren L.

description:
Food is awesome, the atmosphere is nice and quiet, and service is quick.
Very tasty food and a good portion.
author: David S.

description: Pretty authentic Thai cooking. I had the beef larb, and I've also had the duck larb here before. It's not too spicy, but very flavorful. Larb is made of minced meat, sautéed in fish sauce, lime juice and broth with shallots, diced cilantro and mint. The Thai iced tea is also quite delicious here. The service is prompt, although they got my order wrong once. The restaurant itself is very sleek and modern and is quite popular with the local business people during lunch and dinner. The prices are a bit high, but most places in the Financial District are expensive.
author: Jeromy C.

description:
Came here with a reservation and was seated promptly. The interior is really luxurious and the waiter staff are all very professional. The service was pretty good and friendly.

I got the khao nar ped (duck rice bowl) because I was craving duck. It came in a large bowl with lightly seasoned rice, a few slices of cucumber, and a breast of duck laid on top. The duck was rather dry and lacked the deep umami flavor that duck often has. Also, as it was just rice and duck breast and a few pieces of cucumber, there was no variety in texture and each bite felt dry. So I doused it in the sweet and sour sauce that came with the dish, but it did not improve much. It wasn't awful, but it wasn't good. It was very okay, but it came with a price tag of $23 and tax/tip/surcharge put the bill at $30. 

I also feel that thai food tends to be pretty big in portion size but not here so much.

Would have been better with a cheap take out $10 pad Thai :/
author: Grace P.

description:
Delicious food, great service and awesome ambience !!!

I tried vegetariann crispy roll and Pad Mee vegetarian and they were simply fantastic. They have a lot of variety in vegetarian and non vegetarian dishes. Their portion sizes are appropriate for one person. Restaurant is clean, tidy. It is quite big so they should be able to easily fit groups with 10 people. It seems to be a busy restaurant at least on Friday, so I would recommend to reserve in advance.
author: Sanyogita R.

description: I booked  a table in this wonderful establishment to celebrate my husbands birthday, I was excited to finally share the well rounded costumer service and fabulous food choices since I already went here for my company's Christmas party. The interaction I had with the staff was impeccable, both luxury-radiating  and sincere. They greeted me with the biggest smiles and were very enthusiastic to be of service. The food I would say is the perfect balance of heritage and modernity, flavors were very compellingly authentic, fresh, with the twist of contemporary presentation. I was admiring the amount of detail I can find in all aspects of the restaurant, (interior design, utensils, server uniforms, garnishes, and overall energy that Lao Table exudes) very modern yet pays homage to the Lao/Thai Culture). The most beautiful people are those who are ready to share kindness to everyone and it was an honor to meet Kitty, the manager/creative director/overall visionary of the brand Lao Table.   Overall I was beyond  contented to have spent my partners special day in this masterpiece of a restaurant.
author: Alex J.

description:
The attendants are adorable and nice, they help us with literally everything and with a pretty smile on their faces. 

The food tastes great and the prices are not so high as most of the downtown restaurants. 

One thing: some of us ordered basil chicken rice bowl and asked the waitress if they can do it non-spicy for the chili garlic, they said YES but it turned out to be really spicy...... that's probability the only thing you have to notice before going there.
author: Steven L.

description:
My husband and I are here for the first time tonight. 
We had a wonderful experience. The food is similar to Thai but with a unique flair. The House tea was very good and different. It was blue and with some lemon turned purple! It is natural from a particular flower. The food was excellent, I recommend the chocolate soufflé cake with Thai ice cream for dessert. Kitty, the manager was very gracious and makes the experience even better.
author: Kellie M.

description: Very yummy. When they ask about spiciness, medium was pretty spicy for this son of prairie girl. Selection definitely would be familiar to anyone familiar with Thai cuisine. Service was excellent. We were early so it was quiet, but with those high ceilings, I imagine it gets pretty loud when the place is packed. Would definitely go again.
author: David H.

description: I am a huge fan of Osha Thai and this is basically Osha, but not as good. It was a bittersweet feeling when I saw they changed this location from Osha to Lao, but I was willing to give it a chance. This was my favorite Osha location and I loved everything about it from the space to the decor to the food to the neighborhood. I made a lot of memories there, so it's always hard to see that change. Anyway I came here and tried the new menu which was so similar to Osha, but cooked in a different style. It was lackluster to be perfectly honest. I wish that wasn't the case, but it didn't impress me at all. Maybe one day I'll give it another go, but only if someone asks me to. But I'll still be heading over to Osha in its many other locations. Hope this place improves. I'll check in to see if it does.
author: Dexter H.

description: Great menu selection, good imported beers, and a nice environment overall. I had the Gang Beef and it was fantastic!
author: Coleman T.

description: Some of the best food I've ever had. The service wasn't anything special, but also nothing to complain about. Each dish was unique and flavourful, and had its own combination of spices. The servings were large and filling. I left feeling full and satisfied with the experience.
author: Dani P.

description: This is for late post as we actually came here early June for a big group gathering. We were here during the happy hours. Items on the happy hour not necessarily that good; however our friends ordered the non happy hour items and they were nicely presented and quite delicious. Services were excellent even thought it took time to get our order; at least water was always full :))) will come back again for the non happy hours items!
author: Kandice Z.

description: We usually go to thai restaurants because we love pad thai but this restaurant was a surprise: they don't have pad thai on the menu! Instead, I had a delicious chicken with red curry and coconut milk; my husband had beef with pineapple. I really loved the egg rolls, and pineapple fried rice  Overall, the experience was really good and the place is inviting to go back
author: Cristina M.

description:
The food was interesting and tasty. My friend and I both enjoyed our curry dish. They taste pretty different from Indian or Thai curry.

The chef was creative. I found green peppercorn in my curry and thought they complemented the curry well.

The price is high though. We started with a beer, one appetizer, and one main per person. We were going to get desserts but realized it was quickly turning into a $50 per person meal so we skipped it.

I'd say the previous OSHA Thai pricing was about right. There was some FiDi premium, but not too crazy. At $50 per person I would have an even higher expectation than what they delivered.
author: Joseph L.

description: We came here after work and coincidentally hit happy hour! Our intention was to come in for dinner. We ordered the calamari from the happy hour menu and red curry and pork with rice (forgot the name :( ) overall we loved all of our dishes the calamari was nice and crispy with a dipping sauce. I thought the pork was slightly on the salty side but it was great when you combine it with rice. The red curry came with noodles and rice which was so interesting how they served it! I really wonder if food were served that way in Laos. I really wish we were up for drinks that night as they had whole coconuts that they will crack open for you. The only problem I have is that there weren't many selections... I am NOT a fan of chicken  and most of the meals are made of chicken.... I would have loved it even more if I could have ordered my red curry with tofu or pork but I didn't have that option which was sad...
author: Nina Y.

description:
My experience tonight was just beyond underwhelming. My friend and I went to
Lao table tonight because famous Thai chef had a pop up project and we were excited to try his food. Everything started to go downhill when I had to wait 45 minutes between courses. The food was subpar at its best, they served us melted ice cream. The best part of the night was when we saw the bill. The restaurant charged an "automatic 20% " even though they don't deserve it. My friend and I spent four full hours at the restaurant being bored to the max waiting 45 minutes between courses and were "forced" to give 20% tips. I feel like I was robbed.
author: Emily R.

description:
Ate here during the Dreamforce event... so much traffic! Closest parking garage was 555 Mission. Warning, it closes at 8pm so I had to have security walk me to my car. Wasn't bad though.

Good vibes, loud, but you can still hear each other. The food was excellent... we had the grilled calamari, shrimp curry, Lao fried rice, eggplant, tamarind beef, spring rolls, and soufflé dessert.

The calamari comes out whole but cut up in it's shape. It was very tasty! Enough to feed 4. The Lao fried rice came with a little surprise... three chicken wings. Unfair for the fourth person ;)  the beef and eggplant were also standouts. Tip: just asked for items to be mild. You will notice "spicy" listed many times on menu.

The souffle was so so. The drinks are a bit pricey. I would give this spot 5 stars but the language barrier made it tough with ordering- a few mistakes.   The bathrooms are private but they ran out of hand towels. We also made reservations for 7pm and we were seated pretty late. Overall, I would come back!
author: Neville B.

description: Went here Friday for dinner with my husband and friends and really enjoyed it. I was very glad we had a reservation - the wait seemed really long by 7! We ordered the spring rolls, red curry, and Pad Mee "Lao" (all vegetarian) and everything was delicious. I especially enjoyed the spice level on the noodles! The Lao Soda cocktail with fresh watermelon was also excellent. The ambiance was very hip and fun, with pink up lighting and dance music playing, though the volume inside did make it hard to have a real conversation with the other side of the table. Overall I thought Lao Table was good and would come back if I were in this part of town!
author: Lauren R.

description:
The food was bomb!!!! 
Lao fried rice is number one recommendation and basil chicken rice bowl!
The pineapple Millionaire is great too!!
author: Arlene Y.

description: 5-stars across the board! So many wonderful things to say about this place. First off, make your reservations on Yelp. I made reservation for 8:30pm, but called to change to 8:45 and we were still a little late. They were so welcoming and accommodating of my party of 5. Since it was a Wednesday night and my party and I were dining so late, it wasn't overly crowded. The table ordered chicken satay, spring rolls, grilled calamari, pineapple fried rice and a couple ordered pho bowls. Presentations were beautiful arriving to our table on small wooden planks and very abundant amounts. I am a huge fan of calamari, so I was so excited to order the grilled calamari. Actually, I was sold by a photo taken on Yelp of the grilled calamari. It was absolutely delicious. Perfectly cooked, seasoned wonderfully and plentiful for an appetizer (to share) or to have as your entree. Chicken satay is a pretty boring dish for me, but for that protein you may need, it's great! The pineapple fried rice was a hit and definitely stuck out with it's huge chunks of pineapple and chicken. Customer service here was the best. They paid careful attention to keeping our table clean, the waiter was very attentive and they made my daughter feel special by singing happy birthday (accompanied with dimming of the lights and a bell gong). This restaurant is in the heart of the Financial District - on 2nd Street between Howard and Market. Make reservations on Yelp and you're good to go. I have had Thai food plenty of times and many may compare it to that, but there are definitely differences in flavors and seasonings. I'd love to be back, when I am in San Francisco again. I am always so excited to go to ethnic restaurants because I don't get too many places like that in the current state I live in, sadly enough. If you have a big group, check out this restaurant, too; they can accommodate.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Oh geez, where to start on my varied experience with Lao Table? I rarely leave negative reviews, but I hope they see this so changes can be made. I made a reservation here for my birthday over the phone one week in advance. I called the day of the reservation to add one person to my table. I show up Saturday night for my 7pm reservation and they said they believed I had called and canceled it. I said this wasn't true and they argued with me saying I called TWICE that day to cancel. Again, not true. My only conclusion is that there were two Emma's who made a reservation for that night? Me thinks they need to work on their reservation system - especially since another party who had a 7pm reservation said their table was also given away and that the restaurant had "lost" their reservation as well. All in all, we were finally seated at 7:45pm once I put a bit of pressure on them. Yes they were super packed on a Saturday night, but that's the reason I made a reservation well in advance. 

Once we were seated, nobody gave us menus or asked if we liked anything to drink. I think it took about 20 minutes for a waiter to see us, and that was after we asked. 

The good news: attractive decor and location and tasty food. I especially enjoyed the curry and eggplant we had. Portions are smaller than most Thai/Lao places so I'd lean on ordering more than less. 

Lao Table - I hope you fix your service and reservations so no one else has to wait over an hour for service on a special occasion.
author: Emma W.

description: All that we eaten was delicious, the restaurant was clean, they has an excellent servers who helps you to choose and they explain you all that you need. The prices are good.
author: Valeria P.

description: Delicious food and elegant restaurant. We ordered a couple of dishes including a chicken red curry, flat noodles, mango rice and a spring roll appetizer. All were tasty and so appealing! We look forward to coming back!
author: Madelaine K.

description: Came for drinks while waiting for our table at Anchor & Hope. Grabbed two seats at the bar and was Super impressed with the bartender/mixologist. Excellent drinks mixed with all things fresh: herbs, dried chiles, fresh coconut (hammered open at the bar!) pineapple-infused soda, etc. Highly recommend the Pineapple Millionaire drink, which comes in a copper Pineapple. Hands down best drink I've had during this trip.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Hip restaurant that merges Lao and Californian beautifully. 

FOOD:
The turmeric chicken with sticky rice and papaya salad I had was delicious. I loved the bright colors of the chicken and the orchid garnish, the equally bright flavors of the dish, and the plating (The sticky rice comes in a petite banana leaf/grass basket). 

SERVICE: 
We had seats promptly at the bar and attentive servers at lunch. Someone even came out to explain all the items on my colorful plate! 

It was pretty packed even at lunch (which is why we were sat at the bar), so I plan to make a YelpRes next time to enjoy the awesome main space :). I would definitely recommend making a reservation for dinner! 

AMBIANCE:
The decor is incredible--with vaulted ceilings, brightly colored lamps, deep blue-green walls, and modern bar, it was a delight just to sit and drink it all in.
author: Helen W.

description: Great place to try some new and unique food! We got the eggplant dish as well as the curry noodles which were both delicious and more than enough for two very hungry people to share. The service was also excellent with out server being so attentive and helpful in choosing dishes.While the price point is a negative, the quantity and portion size makes up for it. We wish we had enough room in our bellies for one of their desserts but will be back to try one!
author: Rachel N.

description:
I love this restaurant. 
As usual, we tried to visit a new restaurant in SOMA each time we go to the Metreon for a movie. This time, we chose Lao Table. 
It was quite a bit of walking to 2nd street, instead of the restaurants across the street at Yerba Buena. But it was well worth the trek. 
Upon entering, we were greeting by a nice gentleman with a Buddhist bow, with his hands clasped together. 
The restaurant is very nicely appointed. Orchids everywhere, a gold statue of Buddha, bells, lampshades... the blue plates on the table are exotic. 
My husband ordered a whisky drink that came with an elephant keychain. My son had Thai iced tea. 
For appetizer we had the Lao sausage, and the crispy chicken wings. The chicken wings were delicate, different from the thickly breaded Korean wings. Nicely flavored, with lots of fried garlic. The Lao sausage was excellent too, served with lettuce to wrap the slices, with peanuts and fresh herbs, onions and garlic slices... somehow it seemed to miss a dipping sauce. The sausage was perfectly seasoned, but it is just me, I would have liked a dipping sauce. 
The entrees were magnificently displayed on wooden boards, each with a sauce and a small covered bowl of rice. 
The Kobe beef was served sliced, a side of vegetables crudités and apple slices, and a tamarind chili sauce, and sweet rice. Yum! 
The kurobota pork belly came with a glistening cameralized glaze, on a bed of picked vegetables, and a dipping sauce. 
The totally prawns ( name of dish ) red curry had a beautiful explosion of colors: red curry, pink jumbo prawns, white lychees, red and yellow peppers and green herbs, with the rice in a white and blue covered bowl. 
They were all delicious!! 
Time was pressing for the movie, but we also ordered the sweet rice and coconut ice cream. The sweet rice came in two tiny bundles of leaves, sweet rice with red beans and banana. The coconut ice cream ( 2 scoops ) was served inside a whole young coconut. We ate as fast as we could, and I took the coconut with me, ice cream still left inside. And the young coconut meat was another delicious treat after the ice cream was gone.
